questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge for the past 5 days. Menses occur at irregular 20- and 40-day intervals and last 4 to 8 days. She is sexually active with a new partner whom she met 3 months ago, and they use condoms inconsistently. She had a normal Pap smear 5 months ago. She drinks 2 beers every other day. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/75 mm Hg. Examination shows lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination is notable for uterine and adnexal tenderness and small amounts of bloody cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 14,500/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 90 mm/h. A spot urine pregnancy test is negative. An endocervical swab is obtained for nucleic acid amplification testing. The patient is started on ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Typical imaging findings of PID (e.g., edematous, fluid-filled ovarian tubes, free pelvic fluid, and tuboovarian abscesses) can support the diagnosis, and imaging might be warranted if the diagnosis remains unclear or if symptoms persist after empiric treatment. However, when imaging is indicated, either transvaginal ultrasound (US) or MRI is preferred because CT scan involves exposure to radiation and does not provide more diagnostic information than these modalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Tzanck smear is used to detect herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1 and 2 infections. Although this patient is at risk for developing genital herpes, which may cause vaginal discharge, she does not have characteristic genital vesicles or ulcers.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive findings on gonococcal culture can support the diagnosis of PID. However, PID is primarily a clinical diagnosis, and an endocervical swab has already been obtained for nucleic acid amplification testing. Another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy is used as a screening method for premalignant and malignant cervical lesions, usually after an abnormal Pap smear. It is also indicated in cases of postcoital bleeding. Neither of these indications is present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients in their third decade of life, a Pap smear is routinely recommended every 3 years. This patient had a normal Pap smear 5 months ago.

F) CORRECT:

PID is most commonly caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae as a result of unprotected sex, which increases the risk for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Therefore, all patients diagnosed with PID should undergo testing for other STIs, including HIV and syphilis.

Patients with PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that is effective against N. gonorrheae (ceftriaxone) and C. trachomatis (doxycycline) and also provides coverage against anaerobes (metronidazole).
questions.hint: Vaginal discharge in combination with uterine and adnexal tenderness suggests pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID is a clinical diagnosis; a positive test for cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis supports the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive pain while swallowing. She has the feeling that food gets stuck in her throat and is harder to swallow than usual. She has a history of high-grade cervical dysplasia which was treated with conization 12 years ago. Four months ago, she was diagnosed with Graves' disease and started on antithyroid therapy. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has had eight lifetime sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her father died of stomach cancer. She has never smoked and drinks one glass of wine daily. She uses cocaine occasionally. Her current medications include methimazole and a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows several white plaques that can be scraped off easily. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,200/mm3



Platelet count
290,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
12 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time (activated)
38 seconds


Serum



Na+

135 mEq/L


Cl-

104 mEq/L


K+

4.9 mEq/L


Blood urea nitrogen
13 mg/dL


Glucose
90 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 HIV antibody test
positive


In addition to starting antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin can be used to treat oral thrush. However, topical therapy is not effective for the treatment of esophagitis and is therefore not recommended in this patient with symptoms of concomitant Candida esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic commonly used as a prophylactic drug and to treat disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disease in HIV-positive patients. MAC disease manifests with fever, fatigue, diarrhea, weight loss, and/or pulmonary disease. Prophylaxis against MAC is started when the CD4+ count is ≤ 50/mm3 in patients who are not receiving antiretroviral therapy. However, MAC disease does not typically cause dysphagia and odynophagia, and these symptoms should be addressed first. Therefore, azithromycin would not be effective for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral drug used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. While CMV esophagitis can occur in HIV-positive patients and causes dysphagia, it is less common than fungal esophagitis. As this patient has oral thrush on examination, candida esophagitis is more likely. Therefore, ganciclovir is not indicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is an antithyroid drug used to treat hyperthyroidism. This patient has clinical features of esophagitis and is immunocompromised. While there are drugs that can cause esophagitis (e.g., doxycycline, potassium chloride, NSAIDs) and symptoms similar to those seen in this patient, methimazole does not cause esophagitis. Its most serious complication is agranulocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used to treat systemic fungal and protozoal infections. Amphotericin B is only used as a treatment for candidal esophagitis if the organism is resistant against first-line drugs or if there is recurrence of symptoms and an endoscopy is not desired. Therefore, amphotericin B is not indicated in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Although esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) can confirm the diagnosis of Candida esophagitis, most patients with clinical features of the condition and oral thrush on examination can be treated empirically with antifungal therapy. If symptoms do not resolve with empirical therapy, an EGD should be performed.

G) CORRECT:

Systemic antifungal therapy is the most appropriate treatment for patients with suspected Candida esophagitis. Oral fluconazole is the preferred regimen, but intravenous therapy is indicated in patients who do not tolerate oral therapy. Most patients with oral thrush and suspected Candida esophagitis can be treated empirically with systemic antifungal therapy. If symptoms do not resolve with empirical therapy, an EGD should be performed to rule out other causes of esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient has white plaques that can be easily scraped off, indicating oral thrush. The presence of dysphagia suggests concomitant Candida esophagitis.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Eight months ago, he was diagnosed with HIV infection and combined antiretroviral treatment was begun. He feels well. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include lamivudine, zidovudine, atazanavir, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
102 μm3


Leukocyte count
2,600/mm3


Segmented neutrophils
38%


Lymphocytes
54%


Platelet count
150,000/mm3



Serum



Folate
normal


Lactate
6.0 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2)


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.34


pCO2
30 mm Hg


pO2
99 mmHg


HCO3-
14 mEq/L


The drug most likely responsible for this patient's current laboratory findings belongs to which of the following classes of drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Entry inhibitors (e.g., enfuvirtide, maraviroc) are most commonly associated with injection site reactions. Enfuvirtide can also cause fatigue, insomnia, and gastrointestinal distress, while maraviroc is associated with rash, infection, and fever. This patient presents with anemia, neutropenia, and lactic acidosis, none of which is a typical adverse effect of entry inhibitors. Moreover, none of his current medications belong to this class of drugs.

B) INCORRECT:

Integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir) are associated with gastrointestinal intolerance (nausea, diarrhea), headaches, and hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., rash). This patient presents with anemia, neutropenia, and lactic acidosis, none of which is a typical adverse effect of integrase inhibitors. Moreover, none of his current medications belong to this class of drugs.

C) CORRECT:

Mitochondrial toxicity, which may manifest as lactic acidosis, is a classical adverse effect of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as zidovudine and lamivudine. Moreover, zidovudine specifically is associated with bone marrow suppression, which leads to megaloblastic macrocytic anemia and neutropenia. Other drugs of the NRTI class are also associated with their own adverse effects: didanosine and stavudine can cause pancreatitis, while abacavir is associated with an increased risk of hypersensitivity reaction in individuals who are HLA-B*57:01 positive.
Image Description:

1. Attachment: The viral envelope glycoprotein gp120 (cap) binds to CD4 receptors, which are present on certain cells. The gp120-CD4 complex then binds to the host chemokine receptor 5 (CCR5).
– CCR5 antagonists prevent viral attachment to the host cell.

2. Penetration: Viral binding to CCR5 causes a conformational change in the envelope gp41 (stalk), which enables HIV to fuse with and release its capsid into the host cell.
- Fusion inhibitors competitively bind to gp41 and prevent viral fusion with the host cell.

3. Uncoating of the viral capsid to release viral RNA

4. Reverse transcription: Viral RNA is transcribed into viral DNA by viral reverse transcriptase enzymes.
– Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI), nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NtRTI), and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) inhibit the viral reverse transcriptase enzyme.

5. Integration: Newly transcribed viral DNA is integrated into host DNA by viral integrase.
– Integrase inhibitors inhibit viral integrase.

6. Transcription: Newly integrated DNA is used as a template to create copies of viral RNA that will encode for viral proteins.

7. Translation: Newly transcripted viral RNA acts as templates for the synthesis of new viral proteins synthesis. Viral protease enzyme cleaves the long polypeptide chains into shorter, functional viral proteins (e.g., envelope proteins, enzyme proteins).
– Protease inhibitors inhibit viral protease and prevent the generation of functional viral proteins.

8. Release: New viral RNA and viral proteins use a portion of the host cell membrane as a viral envelope and then leave the host cell.

D) INCORRECT:

Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) are associated with hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., rash and Stevens-Johnson syndrome) and some degree of hepatotoxicity. Efavirenz can cause CNS toxicity, which typically manifests as vivid dreams, insomnia, confusion, and hallucinations, while nevirapine is associated with hepatic necrosis. This patient presents with anemia, neutropenia, and lactic acidosis, none of which is a typical adverse effect of NNRTIs. Moreover, none of his current medications belong to this class of drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

Protease inhibitors are associated with hyperglycemia due to peripheral insulin resistance, gastrointestinal intolerance (nausea, diarrhea), and lipodystrophy. Indinavir (and less commonly atazanavir) is also associated with crystal-induced nephropathy and nephrolithiasis. Although this patient is taking a protease inhibitor (atazanavir), neither protease inhibitors (in general) nor atazanavir (specifically) are associated with the anemia, neutropenia, and lactic acidosis seen in his laboratory findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) inhibitors are associated with bone marrow suppression, which can manifest with megaloblastic anemia and neutropenia, as seen in this patient. Although this patient is taking a DHFR inhibitor (trimethoprim), his normal serum folate levels allow trimethoprim-induced bone marrow suppression to be ruled out, as folate is expected to be low in trimethoprim toxicity. Moreover, DHFR inhibitors are not associated with lactic acidosis.
questions.hint: In combination with elevated serum lactate, metabolic acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis (pH < 7.35 and bicarbonate < 22 mEq/L) with decreased PCO2 indicates lactic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 36 weeks' gestation for her first prenatal visit. She confirmed the pregnancy with a home urine pregnancy kit a few months ago but has not yet followed up with a physician. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.6 g/dL


Serum



 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


 Hepatitis C antibody
negative


 HIV antibody

positive


 HIV load

11,000 copies/mL


Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine fetus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?

choices.text: Plan for vaginal delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration when labor occurs
Start combined antiretroviral therapy and schedule cesarean delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration at 38 weeks' gestation
Start combined antiretroviral therapy and schedule vaginal delivery with induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation
Schedule cesarean delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration at 38 weeks' gestation
Schedule vaginal delivery with induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum zidovudine reduces the risk of vertical transmission of HIV during labor and should be administered if the maternal viral load is > 1000 copies/mL, and in patients with a viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL after the risks and benefits have been discussed. However, intrapartum zidovudine alone is not sufficient for reducing the risk of transmission. Furthermore, vaginal delivery is not recommended in pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL near the time of delivery.

B) CORRECT:

Combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is recommended throughout pregnancy in all pregnant women with HIV infection and should be initiated as soon as possible to reduce the viral load and risk of transmission. Effective maternal cART (and neonatal zidovudine therapy) can reduce perinatal HIV transmission to < 2%, compared to a transmission rate of 30% in untreated individuals. In pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL, as seen in this patient, cesarean delivery should be scheduled at 38 weeks to avoid vaginal delivery, which is associated with an increased risk of transmission. In addition, intrapartum zidovudine is indicated to further reduce the risk of neonatal HIV infection (see “Intrapartum management of HIV” table).

Infant antiretroviral prophylaxis is recommended in all newborns of mothers with HIV infection and includes either zidovudine alone for 4 weeks (viral load < 50 copies/mL) or cART for 6 weeks (viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL).

C) INCORRECT:

Combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is recommended throughout pregnancy and should be initiated as soon as possible to reduce the viral load and risk of transmission. Although vaginal delivery may be considered in pregnant women with a viral load ≤ 1000 copies/mL, it is not recommended in patients with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a significant risk of intrapartum transmission. cART generally reduces the viral load considerably within one month, which is not sufficient in this patient at 36 weeks' gestation.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum zidovudine reduces the risk of vertical transmission of HIV during labor and should be administered if the maternal viral load is > 1000 copies/mL, and in patients with a viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL after the risks and benefits have been discussed. However, intrapartum zidovudine alone is not sufficient for reducing the risk of transmission. Cesarean delivery at 38 weeks of gestation is recommended in all pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a lower risk of intrapartum HIV transmission than other methods of delivery.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaginal delivery is not recommended in women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL near the time of delivery because it is associated with an increased risk of HIV transmission. Furthermore, all individuals infected with HIV (regardless of CD4 count) should begin combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) as soon as possible to reduce HIV-associated morbidity and the risk of transmission.

F) INCORRECT:

Cesarean delivery is recommended in all pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a lower risk of intrapartum HIV transmission than other methods of delivery. However, the patient is in the 36th week of pregnancy and the maternal HIV infection does not justify immediate cesarean delivery. This should be scheduled at 38 weeks.
questions.hint: The risk of vertical transmission of HIV from the mother to the fetus is highest during childbirth.

questions.text: A 2300-g (5-lb 1-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 45 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV RNA testing is indicated 14–21 days, 1–2 months, and 4–6 months after birth in infants exposed to HIV.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV antibody testing is not advised for children < 18 months of age, as maternal antibodies still present in the infant's bloodstream can act as confounding factors and invalidate the test.

C) INCORRECT:

Zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine are recommended for HIV PEP in infants born to HIV-positive mothers with HIV and a viral load of ≥ 50 copies/mL. However, a three-drug regimen is not recommended for a mother with a viral load < 50 copies/mL because of the greater risk of adverse effects, such as neutropenia and anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Because HIV transmission will have severe consequences for the neonate, minimization of transmission risk is of paramount importance. Simple reassurance is inappropriate, as other options can help reduce the rate of transmission.

E) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine and nevirapine can be used in combination with zidovudine for HIV PEP in infants if the mother's viral load is ≥ 50 copies/mL. However, this combination is not indicated if the viral load is < 50 copies/mL because of the greater risk of adverse effects.

F) CORRECT:

For infants born to mothers with HIV and a viral load < 50 copies/mL, PEP with zidovudine for 4 weeks is recommended to prevent neonatal transmission of HIV. If the mother's viral load is ≥ 50 copies/mL, a two-drug regimen (zidovudine and nevirapine) or a three-drug regimen (zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine or raltegravir) is recommended.

See "Intrapartum management of HIV" table.
questions.hint: Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for infants born to mothers with HIV infection to decrease the risk of transmission.

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a productive cough. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant has not received any immunizations. She is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of several genetic disorders such as Down syndrome. Patients with Down syndrome have a higher susceptibility to respiratory infections, but cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy, white plaques on the tongue, and chronic diarrhea indicate a more generalized immunodeficiency. In addition, this patient lacks characteristic physical findings of Down syndrome such as micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, and epicanthal folds.

B) INCORRECT:

The dihydrorhodamine test is positive in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD commonly manifests with failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, respiratory infections, and diarrhea in the first year of life. However, infections in CGD are typically recurrent and other manifestations such as skin, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary granulomas are expected. In addition, this disorder is caused by an X-linked recessive defect, but the patient is female, which makes a diagnosis of CGD very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

DNA testing for CFTR mutation is used for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Although patients with CF also have failure to thrive and pulmonary infections, they additionally often develop meconium ileus, and foul-smelling diarrhea due to fat malabsorption, in contrast to this patient's watery diarrhea. Moreover, CF alone would not explain this patient's inguinal and cervical lymphadenopathy and thrush.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is used in the diagnosis of congenital syphilis. Although this patient's mother did not have any prenatal care, and syphilis is a possible congenital infection (TORCH), it typically presents with nasal discharge, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and skin manifestations, none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry of B lymphocytes is used for diagnosing immunodeficiencies due to B-cell abnormalities, such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which usually manifests 3–6 months after birth with recurrent bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia). However, fungal infections, such as candida, are not typical in XLA. Furthermore, lymphoid tissue is not found in patients with XLA, whereas this patient has lymphadenopathy. In addition, XLA is an X-linked recessive disease that typically appears in boys and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis for this female patient.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

F) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests vertical transmission of HIV, for which lack of prenatal care, vaginal delivery, and breastfeeding are risk factors. A polymerase chain reaction test (PCR test) is used to diagnose HIV in children < 18 months of age. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) cannot be used in children < 18 months of age, because maternal HIV IgG antibodies are able to cross the placenta, possibly leading to false-positive results.

HIV testing is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. In pregnant patients with HIV and an unknown viral load, scheduled cesarean delivery is usually recommended at 38 weeks' gestation to decrease the risk of vertical transmission. In mothers with HIV who have infants without HIV, breastfeeding should be avoided if possible. However, in resource-limited countries, breastfeeding may be considered. Maternal adherence to antiretroviral therapy decreases the risk of HIV transmission from breast milk.

G) INCORRECT:

Analysis of T-cell receptor excision circles is used for the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although SCID typically manifests with respiratory infections, chronic diarrhea, thrush, and failure to thrive, it is most often inherited in an X-linked pattern and thus unlikely in a female patient. In addition, lymph nodes and tonsils may be absent in SCID, unlike the lymphadenopathy seen in this girl.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (respiratory infection, chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, thrush) are most likely the result of an impaired immune system. Her mother did not attend any prenatal visits, increasing the possibility of a congenital infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician as a new patient. He feels well. The patient is a refugee who has recently immigrated. His current medications are lamivudine, zidovudine, and indinavir. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension in both parents. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 600 cells/mm3 and an HIV-1 viral load of 104 copies/mL. Which of the following is the most likely adverse effect of this patient's current antiretroviral therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome is an adverse effect that more commonly occurs with nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs), such as nevirapine or efavirenz, than with other antiretroviral drug groups.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe drug-induced hepatotoxicity leading to hepatic failure most commonly occurs with nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) such as nevirapine or efavirenz. This patient's antiretroviral regimen is unlikely to result in severe hepatotoxicity; zidovudine therapy typically only causes mild transient transaminitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity can occur with any drug but is a particularly worrisome known adverse effect of abacavir. This potentially life-threatening syndrome of fever and maculopapular rash occurs most commonly in patients who are HLA-B*57:01 positive. This patient's drug regimen is more likely to cause a different side effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Palmoplantar hyperpigmentation is a rare adverse effect of emtricitabine. Zidovudine can occasionally cause hyperpigmentation of the nails and oral cavity but hyperpigmentation localized to the palms and soles is not an adverse effect of any of this patient's antiretroviral medications.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatitis (both acute and chronic) is a known adverse effect of didanosine (didanosine carries a black box warning for pancreatitis) as well as stavudine. In rare cases, lamivudine and zidovudine can also cause pancreatitis, however, this patient's drug regimen is more likely to cause a different side effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is an adverse effect that among antiretroviral drugs most commonly occurs with a particular formulation of tenofovir (tenofovir disoproxil fumarate). CKD is not a typical adverse effect of lamivudine, zidovudine, or indinavir. In patients with HIV infection, antiretroviral therapy decreases the risk of CKD from HIV-associated nephropathy.

G) CORRECT:

Certain protease inhibitors such as indinavir, atazanavir, and darunavir have poor solubility and significant renal excretion, which leads to crystallization and stone formation (nephrolithiasis or urolithiasis). Stones caused by protease inhibitors are radiolucent and often difficult to detect on imaging. Indinavir can cause kidney stones in up to 20% of patients and is not available in the US since 2019. Other adverse effects of protease inhibitors include metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia) and lipodystrophy.

Zidovudine and lamivudine are nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs). Myelosuppression is an important adverse effect of zidovudine. Lamivudine is well tolerated and usually only causes constitutional symptoms.
questions.hint: This particular adverse effect can also occur with topiramate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to employee health services 30 minutes after a work-related incident. She works as a phlebotomist and reports that blood splashed into her right eye when she was drawing blood from a 30-year-old male patient. Immediately following the incident, she flushed her eye with water for several minutes. The patient from whom she drew blood was admitted for hemoptysis, weight loss, and night sweats. He is an intravenous drug user and is sexually active with several male and female partners. The phlebotomist has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to drawing her blood for viral serologies, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of raltegravir (or dolutegravir), tenofovir, and emtricitabine is the preferred three-drug regimen for HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) following high-risk occupational exposure. The overall risk of transmission is very low but depends on multiple factors, including the type of exposure, the viral load of the source patient, and, in the case of a needle-stick injury, the type of needle involved. While the HIV status of the source patient is unknown, he has multiple risk factors for HIV infection (IV drug user, sexually active), and PEP should be offered as soon as possible, ideally within a few hours but at least within 72 hours.

Other steps that should be taken immediately after occupational exposure include testing the source person for HCV (HCV Ab or HCV RNA), HBV (HBV surface Ag), and HIV (HIV Ag/Ab or HIV Ab, rapid test preferred). Nucleic acid amplification testing (e.g., viral load testing) should not be performed as an initial screening test for HIV because it has a higher rate of false positives than antibody-based tests, and, furthermore, an undetectable HIV viral load in the source patient or the exposed patient does not rule out HIV transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Zidovudine was one of the first antiretrovirals used to treat HIV and is still occasionally used to prevent vertical transmission of HIV. Zidovudine is not recommended for the treatment of occupational exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of tenofovir and emtricitabine is recommended for HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV transmission in patients who are HIV-negative but are at risk of HIV infection (e.g., individuals with a serodiscordant sexual partner or those engaging in high-risk sexual activity). This patient has had a recent occupational exposure, however, meaning a different step is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance would be indicated if there were no true exposure identified, e.g., if the source patient's blood came into contact with skin that was intact or the exposure involved a noninfectious bodily fluid (e.g., feces, saliva, vomit). However, blood coming into contact with the eye is considered a high-risk exposure and this patient is at risk of contracting a bloodborne pathogen; reassurance would be insufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Sofosbuvir and velpatasvir are used for the treatment of hepatitis C (HCV) infection. Currently, there is no postexposure prophylaxis regimen available for patients at risk of HCV transmission. Recommendations for postexposure HCV testing differ, but treatment is only recommended for documented infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine should be administered in cases of occupational exposure when the HBV vaccination status of the health care worker is incomplete or unknown. This woman's vaccinations are up-to-date and, as a healthcare worker, this would include complete HBV vaccination. No further action is required to prevent hepatitis B infection.
questions.hint: This phlebotomist's mucous membranes were contaminated by blood from a source patient with risk factors for a bloodborne disease.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive breast enlargement. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV infection and started treatment with antiretroviral medications. Examination shows a soft, non-tender, ill-defined swelling at the nape of the neck. The cheeks appear hollowed. Serum studies show increased total cholesterol and LDL concentration. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nevirapine can in some cases cause dyslipidemia, but it would not cause lipodystrophy with abnormal fat distribution, as seen in this patient. Instead, notable side effects include hepatotoxicity and rash.

B) INCORRECT:

Enfuvirtide is a well-tolerated medication that would not be expected to cause lipodystrophy with abnormal fat distribution as seen in this patient. Instead, a notable side effect is skin reactions at injection sites.

C) CORRECT:

Therapy with indinavir, a protease inhibitor, increases the risk of developing HIV-associated lipodystrophy. Other HIV antiretrovirals that can also cause these symptoms include other protease inhibitors as well as some nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (especially zidovudine and stavudine).

Reversion of lipodystrophy does not occur after stopping treatment with indinavir or other protease inhibitors, but GHRH analogs (i.e., tesamorelin) can be used to treat HIV-associated lipodystrophy.
Image Description:

A disturbed distribution of subcutaneous fat with a major loss of buccal and temporal fat results in the appearance of a sunken face while the dorsocervical fat pad is greatly enlarged.

These findings are characteristic of lipodystrophy and can be a side effect of antiretroviral therapy with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors such as stavudine or tenofovir.

D) INCORRECT:

While raltegravir, an integrase inhibitor, can cause hypercholesterolemia and increased levels of glucose, it is not known to cause lipodystrophy with abnormal fat distribution as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

While other nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, such as zidovudine and stavudine, can cause lipodystrophy, it is not a known side effect of abacavir. Instead, notable side effects include bone marrow suppression and abacavir-related hypersensitivity syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient has been on long-term antiretroviral therapy for HIV and displays signs of acquired lipodystrophy (disproportionate fat deposition, dorsocervical fat lump “Buffalo hump,” peripheral wasting, breast enlargement, and labs suggestive of dyslipidemia).

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. He has been nonadherent with his antiretroviral medication regimen for several years. He appears chronically ill and fatigued. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 405/mm3. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Encapsulated yeast on India ink staining of blood

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Violaceous skin lesions in a patient with HIV describe Kaposi sarcoma. HIV patients are at a higher risk of Kaposi sarcoma at variable CD4 counts, even above 400/mm3.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary cavitations in a patient with HIV may be caused by pulmonary aspergillosis, pneumocystis pneumonia, or tuberculosis. HIV patients have an increased risk of pulmonary aspergillosis primarily at CD4 counts below 100/mm3, pneumocystis pneumonia primarily at CD4 below 200/mm3, and tuberculosis primarily at CD4 below 400/mm3.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal mucosa with white plaques in a patient with HIV describes Candida esophagitis. Risk of this infection increases primarily among patients with CD4 counts below 100/mm3.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotton-wool spots on the fundus in a patient with HIV is a classic description of CMV retinitis. HIV patients with CD4 counts below 50/mm3 are at higher risk of CMV infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Encapsulated yeast on India ink staining of blood or cerebrospinal fluid in a patient with HIV describes systemic infection with Cryptococcus neoformans. The risk of cryptococcal meningitis increases especially among patients with CD4 counts below 100/mm3.

F) INCORRECT:

Multifocal demyelination on brain MRI in a patient with HIV describes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is primarily seen in HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200/mm3.

G) INCORRECT:

Multiple ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI in a patient with HIV is observed in cerebral toxoplasmosis. The risk for cerebral toxoplasmosis increases primarily among patients with a CD4 count below 100/mm3.

Hodgkin lymphoma also causes ring-enhancing lesions, but they are usually solitary. For HIV-associated Hodgkin lymphoma, the CD4 count can vary, while a primary CNS lymphoma typically occurs at CD4 counts below 100/mm3.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary ground-glass opacities are a classic finding of Pneumocystis pneumonia. It is seen primarily in patients with HIV with CD4 counts below 200/mm3.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

There is widespread increased attenuation of the lung parenchyma with preservation of bronchial and vascular markings (ground-glass opacification; green overlay). In the posterior lungs, markings are obscured by consolidation (red overlay). Scattered small gas-filled cystic spaces (pneumatoceles; examples indicated by white arrows) are present bilaterally.

Extensive ground-glass opacification is a frequent feature of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and may be accompanied by pneumatoceles.

S: sternum; AA: ascending Aorta; PT: pulmonary trunk; DA: descending aorta; V: vertebra; RMB: right mainstem bronchus; LMB: left mainstem bronchus
questions.hint: This patient has a CD4 T-cell count below 500/mm3, but greater than 200/mm3, putting him at risk for several opportunistic infections, including oral hairy leukoplakia, oral thrush, HHV-8 infection, and squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting an experiment to develop a new drug against HIV infection. HIV-infected and uninfected CD4 T-cell lines are mixed in-vitro with a chemically modified synthetic peptide triazole complex. The complex is found to have a high binding affinity to the gp120 protein, irreversibly inhibiting its function and reducing CD4 T cell infection. Inhibition of which of the following steps of HIV infection is the most likely therapeutic effect of this experimental drug?

choices.text: Incorporation of viral genome into host cell DNA
Fusion and entry into CD4 T-cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incorporation of the HIV genome into the DNA of host CD4 T cells is mediated by the HIV enzyme integrase. Inhibition of this step is the mechanism of action of integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir, and elvitegravir). The experimental drug described in this vignette has a high affinity for gp120, which has a different role in HIV infection and pathogenesis.

B) INCORRECT:

After HIV has infected a host cell, the HIV enzyme reverse transcriptase is responsible for the transcription of the viral genome from RNA into dsDNA. Inhibition of this step of HIV replication is the mechanism of action of reverse transcriptase inhibitors. The experimental drug described here has a high affinity for gp120, which has a different role in HIV infection and pathogenesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Fusion and entry of HIV into host CD4 T cells are mediated by the HIV envelope glycoprotein 41 (gp41). Inhibition of gp41 would result in decreased HIV fusion into the host cells, and is the mechanism of action of fusion inhibitors (e.g., enfuvirtide). The experimental drug described here has a high affinity for gp120, which has a different role in HIV infection and pathogenesis.

D) INCORRECT:

HIV proteases mediate the assembly of viral particles (virions) and are essential for maturation of new viruses. Inhibition of this step of HIV replication is the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors (e.g., ritonavir, indinavir, lopinavir). The experimental drug described in this vignette has a high affinity for gp120, which has a different role in HIV infection and pathogenesis.

E) CORRECT:

The HIV envelope glycoprotein 120 (gp120) binds to CD4 receptors on host T-helper cells and macrophages. Gp120 functions as a docking protein for the virus and is essential for infection of host cells. A drug that inhibits gp120 would inhibit the attachment of HIV virus to host CD4 T-cells.
questions.hint: Glycoprotein 120 (gp120) is exposed on the surface of the HIV envelope.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with HIV on antiretroviral therapy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His HIV viral load is 559 copies/mL (N<49). His physician is concerned about the development of drug resistance. The result of HIV genotype testing shows reduced viral susceptibility to darunavir and ritonavir. Which of the following molecular processes is most likely affected by this mutation?

choices.text: Integration of DNA into the host genome
Synthesis of DNA from an RNA template
Binding of glycoproteins to T-cell receptors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Integrase inhibitors, like raltegravir, inhibit the HIV enzyme integrase, which is encoded by the pol gene and functions to incorporate viral DNA into the host genome. As both darunavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors, mutations that confer resistance to these medications affect a different mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), like zidovudine and lamivudine, and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs), like nevirapine and efavirenz, both inhibit reverse transcriptase, a viral enzyme that is encoded by the pol gene and functions by synthesizing DNA from an RNA template. As both darunavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors, mutations that confer resistance to these medications affect a different mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines impede binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to ribosomes, inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis by blocking peptidyltransferase. As both darunavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors, mutations that confer resistance to these medications affect a different mechanism.

D) CORRECT:

The HIV life cycle depends on protease enzymes to cleave newly made polypeptides (e.g., Gag-Pol polypeptide) into functional viral proteins (e.g., capsid proteins, reverse transcriptase and protease enzymes). Protease inhibitors such as darunavir and ritonavir block this step, leading to the release of immature virions that are incapable of infecting new cells. Protease inhibitor resistance is typically mediated by mutations in the pol gene, which leads to the inability of protease inhibitors to bind to HIV protease, with the end result that the virus can continue posttranslational modification of its protein precursors.

E) INCORRECT:

Enfuvirtide, a fusion inhibitor, inhibits the fusion of the HIV virus with the host cell by binding the viral glycoprotein Gp41, which is encoded by the env gene. Gp41 normally facilitates the viral entry into the host cell by interacting with T cell surface proteins (e.g., CD4). As both darunavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors, mutations that confer resistance to these medications affect a different mechanism.
questions.hint: Darunavir and ritonavir both inhibit the HIV enzyme protease.

questions.text: An investigator is studying an experimental treatment for HIV infection that inhibits the maturation of new HIV virions. Patients who are taking the drug are observed for several years and side effects are recorded. A correlation is established between the drug and the development of impaired glucose tolerance. In addition, a significant portion of the patients who take the drug for several years develop kidney stones and show increased fat accumulation in the neck with loss of subcutaneous fat in the face and extremities. Which of the following processes is most likely targeted by this drug?

choices.text: Viral DNA integration into host DNA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of viral entry into host cells is the mechanism of action of entry inhibitors such as enfuvirtide and maraviroc. Enfuvirtide binds to gp41, which prevents fusion, while maraviroc binds to CCR5, which prevents docking. Side effects of fusion inhibitors (e.g., enfuvirtide) include skin reactions at the injection site (e.g., erythema, cysts, and nodules), cough, runny nose, and headache. Side effects of maraviroc include upper respiratory tract infection and, in severe cases, hepatotoxicity accompanied by severe rash or systemic allergic reactions. Neither drug is associated with impaired glucose tolerance or nephrolithiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Inhibition of viral polypeptide cleavage is the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors (PIs) such as ritonavir and indinavir. HIV virions require proteases that cleave polypeptides in order to generate viral proteins (such as reverse transcriptase and even protease itself) and assemble mature virion particles. PIs block this step, leading to the release of immature virions that are incapable of infecting new cells. The insulin resistance caused by PIs is due to inhibition of insulin-dependent glucose transporters (GLUT-4), but the mechanism of fat accumulation seen with protease inhibitors is not well understood. Other side effects of PIs include nausea, diarrhea, nephrolithiasis, and crystal-induced nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of viral DNA integration into host DNA is the mechanism of action of integrase inhibitors such as raltegravir, elvitegravir, and dolutegravir. Side effects of integrase inhibitors include muscle pain, nausea, diarrhea, insomnia, rash, and increased creatine kinase and amylase levels. Integrase inhibitors are not associated with impaired glucose tolerance.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral budding from host cells is mediated by host endosomal sorting complexes required for transport (ESCRT) machinery. Inhibition of this process prevents viral release, not maturation. Moreover, there is no antiviral drug that affects this step of the viral replication cycle.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of reverse transcriptase is the mechanism of action of non-nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) such as nevirapine and efavirenz. All NNRTIs can cause hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) and varying degrees of hepatotoxicity. Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI) also inhibit the reverse transcription of viral RNA by serving as competitive substrates that terminate proviral DNA synthesis. In rare cases, certain NRTIs (e.g., zidovudine, stavudine) can cause lipodystrophy and impaired glucose tolerance. However, this rare side effect would not explain the significant number of patients affected in this study. Moreover, neither NNRTIs nor NRTIs are associated with nephrolithiasis.
questions.hint: This drug inhibits an HIV enzyme that catalyzes a critical step in virion maturation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after being admitted to the hospital for oral and esophageal candidiasis. His CD4+ T lymphocyte count is 180 cells/mm3. An HIV antibody test is positive. Genotypic resistance assay shows the virus to be susceptible to all antiretroviral therapy regimens and therapy with dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine is initiated. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings would be most likely on follow-up evaluation 3 months later?



CD4+/CD8+ ratio
HIV RNA
HIV antibody test



A
↓
↑
negative


B
↑
↑
negative


C
↑
↓
positive


D
↓
↑
positive


E
↓
↓
negative
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decreased CD4+/CD8+ ratio, increased HIV RNA count, and negative HIV antibody testing would be consistent with the acute phase of HIV (e.g., window period), in which the virus is actively replicating but has not yet triggered an antibody response. This constellation of findings is not consistent with the initiation of antiretroviral therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased CD4+/CD8+ ratio, increased HIV RNA, and negative HIV antibody testing are not consistent with the initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART). HIV antibody testing might be negative during the window period or negative due to slow seroconversion but would not turn negative after initiation of ART.

C) CORRECT:

HIV infects CD4+ lymphocytes, leading to a decrease in CD4+ T cells and subsequent immunodeficiency with an increased risk of opportunistic infections (e.g., candidal esophagitis). In the absence of HIV resistance to antiretroviral therapy (ART), an increase in CD4+ T cell concentration with little to no increase in CD8+ T cell concentration is expected in the first three months, resulting in an increased CD4+/CD8+ ratio. Additionally, a decreased HIV viral load (e.g., HIV RNA concentration) can be anticipated in response to ARTs. The HIV antibody test remains positive despite treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased CD4+/CD8+ ratio, increased HIV RNA, and positive HIV antibody testing are findings that may be seen in a patient with HIV not receiving treatment or who has failed treatment (e.g., due to medication non-compliance or drug resistance). Treatment failure is highly unlikely in a patient newly diagnosed with a susceptible strain of HIV and a different constellation of findings is more likely.
Image Description:

Graph showing typical cell counts, antibody levels, and viral loads during different stages of untreated HIV infection/AIDS

The dashed line at the level of 500 cells/mm3 represents a state of moderate immunocompromise.

CD4+ or CD8+ thresholds at which select common opportunistic infections most frequently occur:
I (< 200 cells/mm3): pneumocystis pneumonia, histoplasma capsulatum
II (< 100 cells/mm3): cryptococcal meningitis, candida esophagitis, cerebral toxoplasmosis
III (< 50 cells/mm3): CMV infection, atypical mycobacterial infections

E) INCORRECT:

A decreased CD4+/CD8+ ratio, decreased HIV RNA, and negative HIV antibody testing are not consistent with the initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART). HIV antibody testing can be negative during the window period (e.g., acute HIV infection) or due to slow seroconversion. However, a previous positive antibody test will not become negative within 12 weeks of initiating ART.
questions.hint: Esophageal candidiasis is an opportunistic infection and AIDS-defining condition that is usually associated with a CD4+ count < 100 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue. During this period, he has also had a 7.7-kg (17-lb) weight loss, despite having a normal appetite. He is sexually active with 3 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 570/mm3 and the viral load is 104 copies/mL. Treatment with lamivudine, zidovudine, and indinavir is begun. The patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperpigmentation is an adverse effect of emtricitabine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), but not of lamivudine, zidovudine, or indinavir.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatotoxicity is an adverse effect of nevirapine, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Other side effects of NNRTIs include CNS toxicity (associated with efavirenz) and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. This patient, however, is not taking an NNRTI.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity can occur with any drug but is particularly associated with abacavir, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). Such an abacavir-related hypersensitivity reaction occurs most commonly in patients who are HLA-B*57:01 positive and can be life-threatening. Thus, testing for HLA-B*57:01 must be performed prior to starting any patient on abacavir. This patient's drug regimen does not include any abacavir and is therefore unlikely to cause a hypersensitivity reaction.

D) CORRECT:

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor that has poor solubility and significant renal excretion, which leads to crystallization and stone formation (urolithiasis) in up to 20% of patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatitis (both acute and chronic) is a known adverse effect of didanosine and stavudine, which are nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Pancreatitis is not a known adverse effect of lamivudine, indinavir, or even zidovudine (despite it also being an NRTI).

F) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome is an adverse effect that more commonly occurs with non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, such as nevirapine and efavirenz, than other classes of antiretroviral drugs.
questions.hint: Indinavir is the most likely antiretroviral drug to cause adverse effects in this patient.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Ten months ago, he was diagnosed with HIV infection and appropriate antiretroviral therapy was initiated. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show increased viral load despite ongoing treatment. His pharmacotherapy is switched to a new combination drug regimen including an agent that binds to glycoprotein 41. The expected effect of this drug is most likely due to inhibition of which of the following?

choices.text: Viral docking and attachment to host cells
Viral genome integration into host cells
Viral fusion and entry into host cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV particle assembly occurs as the various viral proteins and RNAs are packaged into a nascent virion. Protease inhibitors, such as indinavir, prevent the cleavage of the gp160 protein into gp120 and gp41, a necessary step in virion maturation, arresting the virus in an immature state. Glycoprotein 41 inhibitors are unable to attach to HIV particles until the virus is fully assembled and, therefore, have no effect on virion assembly.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV docking on host cells is the first step in viral entry into the cell. CCR5 antagonists such as maraviroc inhibit HIV docking by interfering with gp120 interactions with CCR5 co-receptors on host cells, However, gp41 is not involved in the docking process of HIV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of HIV genome transcription occurs through the interference of HIV reverse transcriptase, which copies the single-stranded viral RNA into a double-stranded DNA. This can be achieved either by the use of competitive inhibitors (nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors) or noncompetitive inhibitors (non-nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitors). Binding of gp41 is not associated with this process.

D) INCORRECT:

Once the single-stranded HIV RNA is transcribed into a double-stranded DNA, the viral protein integrase incorporates the viral DNA into the host's chromosome. Inhibition of viral integrases with drugs such as raltegravir would halt the viral replication cycle. However, gp41 is not involved in this process.

E) CORRECT:

HIV fusion and entry into the host cell requires docking of the viral gp120 with CD4 receptors and a co-receptor. This is followed by a conformational change of gp41 that allows fusion of the viral and cellular membranes. Fusion inhibitors such as enfuvirtide are peptides that bind to gp41, disrupting its function and thereby preventing viral entry into the host cells. Enfuvirtide is reserved as a salvage therapy in cases of resistance. The other side effects of enfuvirtide besides injection site reactions are fatigue and diarrhea.
questions.hint: This medication can only be administered parenterally. It is known to cause localized skin reactions at the site of injection.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with an HIV infection comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, combined antiretroviral therapy consisting of dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine was initiated. Laboratory studies show a decrease in the CD4 count and an increase in the viral load despite ongoing treatment. The patient is switched to a new treatment regimen, including a drug that acts by preventing viral DNA synthesis without undergoing intracellular phosphorylation. Which of the following is the most likely drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enfuvirtide, which does not require intracellular phosphorylation for activation, is a fusion inhibitor that antagonizes extracellular viral protein gp41, inhibiting viral entry by preventing fusion with the host cell. It does not, however, inhibit viral DNA synthesis.

B) CORRECT:

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Without requiring intracellular phosphorylation, NNRTIs act as noncompetitive inhibitors of viral reverse transcriptase, thereby inhibiting reverse transcription of viral RNA to DNA and preventing viral DNA synthesis.

Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) are prodrugs that require phosphorylation by intracellular kinases and are thus reliant upon kinase for activation and efficacy. Kinase availability and activity vary depending on cell functionality or activation state.

C) INCORRECT:

Ritonavir, which does not require intracellular phosphorylation for activation, is a protease inhibitor that works by inhibiting cleavage of viral proteins. This results in the production of immature and ineffective viral proteins but does not affect viral DNA synthesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Raltegravir, which does not require intracellular phosphorylation for activation, is an integrase inhibitor that prevents integration of viral DNA into host DNA, therefore preventing viral DNA replication. It does not, however, inhibit viral DNA synthesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine inhibits viral DNA synthesis through antagonism of viral reverse transcriptase. Lamivudine, however, acts as an NRTI, which requires intracellular phosphorylation for activation.
questions.hint: Unlike nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), which require intracellular phosphorylation to be converted into the active form, non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) do not require phosphorylation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. He was diagnosed with HIV 6 years ago and has been on highly active antiretroviral therapy with emtricitabine, tenofovir, and darunavir. He reports that he has been adherent with his medication regimen. His last CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 520/mm3 and HIV viral load was undetectable. Today, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 410/mm3 and his HIV viral load is 240 copies/mL. Further evaluation shows resistance to emtricitabine and tenofovir. Mutations in which of the following genes are most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The tat gene in HIV codes for the Tat protein (trans-activator of transcription), a nonstructural protein that increases the efficiency of viral gene transcription. Even though a vaccine targeting this protein is under investigation, there is no drug on the market that acts on the Tat protein. So a mutation in the tat gene cannot be a reason for drug resistance in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The structural pol gene in HIV codes for a polyprotein that consists of the viral enzymes protease, integrase, and reverse transcriptase. These enzymes are critical for viral replication. A mutation in this gene can result in altered reverse transcriptase structure and therefore induce resistance to reverse transcriptase inhibitors such as NRTI, as observed in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The rev gene in HIV codes for the rev protein, which is involved in exporting viral mRNA to the cytoplasm from the host cell's nucleus. This protein is considered a good target for future development of antiretroviral therapy. However, the drugs of this patient's HAART regimen have a different mechanism of action; therefore a mutation in the rev gene cannot be a reason for drug resistance in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The gag gene codes for core structural proteins such as p24 capsid protein and nucleocapsid proteins. These proteins are involved in the assembly and release of retrovirus particles. A mutation in the gag gene has been associated with resistance to protease inhibitors but not reverse transcriptase inhibitors.

E) INCORRECT:

The env gene in HIV codes for the envelope proteins, gp41 and gp120. These glycoproteins enable the virus to target and infect specific host cells. A mutation in the variable domain of the env gene, involving gp120, has been associated with resistance to CCR5 inhibitors (e.g., maraviroc), which inhibit viral attachment to host cells. Nevertheless, CCR5 inhibitors are not part of this patient's HAART regimen. So a mutation in the env gene cannot be a reason for drug resistance in this patient.
questions.hint: Emtricitabine (a nucleoside analog) and tenofovir (a nucleotide analog) are reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Reverse transcriptase is a viral enzyme that is encoded by one of the HIV structural genes.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the mechanism of HIV infection in cells obtained from a human donor. The effect of a drug that impairs viral fusion and entry is being evaluated. This drug acts on a protein that is cleaved off of a larger glycosylated protein in the endoplasmic reticulum of the host cell. The protein that is affected by the drug is most likely encoded by which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The rev gene encodes a regulatory protein that acts to induce the transition from the early to the late phase of HIV gene expression. Deactivation or inhibition of this protein has no effect on viral fusion and entry.

B) INCORRECT:

The gag gene encodes for the proteins p24 (inner capsid membrane proteins) and p17 (outer membrane). Deactivation or inhibition of these proteins does not affect viral fusion and cellular entry.

C) INCORRECT:

The pol gene encodes for the enzymes reverse transcriptase (required to convert viral RNA to DNA), aspartate protease, and integrase (required to insert the viral genes into the host genome). Each of these enzymes is of special importance in the treatment of HIV and are targets of numerous HIV treatment medications. Deactivation or inhibition of these proteins, however, does not affect viral fusion and cellular entry.

D) CORRECT:

The structural gene env encodes for the proteins gp120 and gp41. These two proteins are required for initial infection and entry into host cells by the HIV virion. The virus attaches to CD4+ receptors on T cells via its gp120 glycoprotein, while fusion and entry are mediated via the gp41 glycoprotein. These vital proteins have become a target for drugs like enfuvirtide, a fusion inhibitor that competitively binds to the viral protein gp41 and thereby prevents fusion of HIV with its target cell.

E) INCORRECT:

The tat gene encodes for a transcription regulatory protein that is one of the first HIV proteins to be expressed after infection occurs. It is absolutely required for the initiation of the HIV genome transcription. This protein stimulates transcription from the viral long terminal repeat promoter. Deactivation or inhibition of this protein does not impede viral fusion and entry.
questions.hint: The drug that is being evaluated is most likely enfuvirtide, which binds glycoprotein 41 (gp41) to inhibit viral fusion and entry. Gp41, along with gp120, is formed after cleavage of gp160 in the endoplasmic reticulum of an HIV-infected host cell.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has been inconsistently taking combined antiretroviral therapy for the past 5 years. She did not receive any childhood vaccinations because her parents were against them. During the consultation, the patient says that she wants to catch up on the missed vaccinations. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of 180/mm3. Administration of which of the following vaccines should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Bordetella pertussis is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Human papillomavirus (HPV) is an inactivated vaccine. One of the main benefits of vaccination is protection against HPV-associated cervical cancer. HPV immunization is approved for individuals 11–26 years of age. Patients with HIV should receive HPV immunization during this same interval. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

C) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Haemophilus influenzae (Hib vaccine) is an inactivated vaccine that prevents invasive infection with H. influenzae type b (Hib). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Hepatitis B virus is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines. In fact, it is strongly recommended that patients with HIV receive the hepatitis B vaccination because of the elevated risk of chronic infection in this patient group.

E) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Clostridium tetani is a toxoid vaccine (inactivated vaccine). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for toxoid-based immunization.

F) CORRECT:

The vaccine against varicella zoster virus is a live attenuated vaccine. It is recommended in HIV patients with a CD4 count > 200/mm3. However, a CD4 count of 180/mm3, as seen in this patient, is a contraindication for live vaccines (such as varicella, yellow fever, mumps, measles, and rubella) because of the risk of vaccine-related reactivation of the attenuated virus.
questions.hint: Live attenuated vaccines should be avoided in patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 200/mm3.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain and chronic diarrhea. He has had 3 episodes of otitis media since birth. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated but his mother received no prenatal care. She is a known intravenous drug user. The boy's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows thick white plaques on the surface of his tongue that can be easily scraped off with a tongue blade. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antimycotic agent that is commonly used to treat oral candidiasis, which this patient has. However, there is no indication that this patient would have required fluconazole as prophylaxis. Moreover, it does not prevent vertical virus transmission, which is the underlying cause of his condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat neonatal syphilis and congenital group B streptococcus (GBS) infections. Pregnant women without adequate prenatal care are particularly at risk of transmitting these infections to their fetus. However, neonatal syphilis manifests with facial deformities (e.g., saddle nose) and sensorineural deafness, and GBS is a common causative pathogen of neonatal sepsis, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of an HIV infection. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that significantly decreases the vertical virus transmission rate. In pregnant women with HIV infection and no previous treatment, effective maternal cART and neonatal zidovudine can reduce the rate of vertical transmission from approx. 30% to less than 2%. Zidovudine is one of the few antiretroviral medications that is approved throughout pregnancy and for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis in neonates.

The p24 plasma antigen detection is used as screening tests for HIV infection. p24 is a component of the HIV capsid.

D) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is used as post-exposure prophylaxis in patients that had close contact with individuals infected with Haemophilus influenzae type B or Neisseria menigitidis. H. influenzae is a common cause of otitis media. However, this patient also presents with failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and oral candidiasis, which are inconsistent with H. influenzae infection. N. menigitidis causes meningococcal meningitis, which presents acutely with high fever, vomiting, irritability, and nuchal rigidity. Infection with N. meningitidis is not consistent with this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat cytomegalovirus infections. CMV can be transmitted vertically from mother to fetus. Typical symptoms of CMV infection include meningoencephalitis and vesicular lesions, and neonates with CMV infection often have seizures, impaired hearing, skin rash, and chorioretinitis, none of which are seen in this patient. Congenital CMV does not typically cause chronic diarrhea, recurrent otitis media, or oral candidiasis.
questions.hint: This patient's failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, recurrent otitis media, and oral candidiasis are concerning for vertical virus transmission. A virology panel on this patient will most likely be positive for the p24 plasma antigen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and fatigue. He also has nonbloody diarrhea with up to 4 bowel movements per day that began about 2 weeks ago. This morning, he could not go to work because of chills and generalized muscle aches. He had primary syphilis around 10 years ago and was treated with an antibiotic. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Three months ago, he adopted a cat from a local animal shelter. He has not traveled out of the United States in the past year. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs but drinks several alcoholic beverages every weekend. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender preauricular, cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are two tender, shallow, sharply demarcated ulcers with white bases and surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa. The left tonsil is enlarged with no exudate. Several muscles on his arms and legs are tender to palpation with no weakness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results from a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Perform serum testing for Bartonella henselae antibodies

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of nonspecific symptoms such as fever, fatigue, diarrhea, and myalgias, along with findings of generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, nonexudative tonsillitis, and oral mucosal ulcers in a patient with multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use suggests acute retroviral syndrome. The best initial test to diagnose HIV infection is an antigen/antibody combination test (screening test), which detects both HIV antigen (p24) and anti-HIV antibodies as early as 14 days after transmission. If the combination test is negative and acute HIV infection is strongly suspected, an HIV RNA test (viral load test) may be performed because this test can detect an infection before seroconversion (5–10 days after transmission). In patients with a positive screening test, an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay is used to confirm the diagnosis. If the patient has a positive screening test but the confirmatory test is negative, an HIV RNA test must be performed. Because patients with acute HIV infection have an elevated viral load, the probability of HIV transmission is increased. Patients should start antiretroviral therapy as soon as possible and be counseled on reducing the risk of HIV transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

A colonoscopy with intestinal biopsies is used to confirm the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which can manifest with fever, fatigue, and nonbloody diarrhea. Moreover, IBD can be associated with aphthous stomatitis manifesting with oral mucosal ulcers. However, patients with IBD typically present with chronic abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea, which are not seen here. Additionally, IBD is not commonly associated with generalized lymphadenopathy and myalgias.

C) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture is used to diagnose acute bacterial tonsillitis (most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes). This condition manifests with sudden onset of fever, tonsillitis, and lymphadenopathy. However, patients with acute bacterial tonsillitis typically present with exudative tonsillitis and tender lymphadenopathy restricted to cervical lymph nodes whereas this patient's oral findings are nonexudative and his lymphadenopathy is generalized. Moreover, bacterial tonsillitis usually does not cause myalgia, diarrhea, or oral ulcerations.

D) INCORRECT:

EBV serology is used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected infectious mononucleosis. This condition causes fever, fatigue, myalgias, tonsillitis, and generalized lymphadenopathy. However, tonsillitis in patients with mononucleosis is exudative and lymphadenopathy is usually tender. Additionally, diarrhea and oral ulcerations are not common. Finally, this patient is 35 years of age whereas patients with mononucleosis are usually younger (peak incidence: 15–24 years of age).

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional lymph node biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis of lymphoma, which can manifest with fever, fatigue, and nontender lymphadenopathy. While lymphadenopathy in Hodgkin lymphoma is usually localized, non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) can cause generalized lymphadenopathy, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, aggressive forms of NHL can have a very acute onset. However, diarrhea, oral mucosal ulcers, and myalgia are not common in patients with lymphoma. Night sweats and weight loss are constitutional symptoms expected in patients with lymphoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum testing for Bartonella henselae antibodies can be used to diagnose cat scratch disease. This disease can cause fever and lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen in this patient, who recently adopted a cat. However, lymphadenopathy in cat scratch disease is usually tender and localized near the site of inoculation, not generalized and nontender as in this patient. Moreover, B. henselae infection does not cause nonexudative tonsillitis, oral ulcerations, or diarrhea.
questions.hint: Early detection of this patient's condition can prevent long-term complications such as lymphoma, candidiasis, and disseminated mycobacterial infection.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She was diagnosed with HIV infection 15 years ago and has been treated with lamivudine, abacavir, and efavirenz. The patient reports that she has been taking all medications regularly. She has no other personal or family history of serious illness. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her current CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 773/mm3 and has been within the reference range for more than 10 years. The patient expresses concerns about her long-term prognosis and the risk of dying from her condition. If this patient continues to adhere to antiretroviral therapy, she is at greatest risk of death from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In individuals with HIV, the early initiation and extended use of cART assists in maintaining a normal CD4 count, which results in a significant decrease in HIV-related mortality and proportional mortality ratios resembling those of the general population. Patients who are HIV-positive start to experience age-related comorbid conditions more often, such as hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and/or accelerated atherosclerosis. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) in particular has emerged as an important cause of morbidity and mortality in individuals with HIV. Both HIV infection and smoking are independent risk factors for CVD. Considering that, in the United States, CVD is the leading cause of death in the age-pooled general population as well as among people over 65 years of age, this 67-year-old patient with a normal CD4+ count and no additional comorbid conditions is at greatest risk of death from CVD as long as adherence to cART is maintained.

B) INCORRECT:

Opportunistic infections are a leading cause of death in individuals with HIV and therapy nonadherence. The risk of opportunistic infections increases significantly when HIV leads to severe immunosuppression (i.e., CD4+ cell count of < 200 cells/μL). This patient is adherent to her treatment and has had a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count within the reference range for more than 10 years. Therefore, death due to an opportunistic infection is unlikely as long as adherence to antiretroviral therapy is maintained.

C) INCORRECT:

In the United States, life-threatening unintentional injury (UI) is the third leading cause of death in the age-pooled general population and the most common cause of death in people aged 1–44 years. While older age (> 65 years) is considered a risk factor for UIs, UI is not one of the top three most common causes of death in this age group. Given that the risk of UI is not affected by HIV and that this patient has no additional risk factors or comorbid conditions to facilitate an injury (e.g., delirium, gait disturbances), a different cause of death is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

HIV infection and cigarette smoking are risk factors for cancer (e.g., cervical cancer).
