What is the most appropriate next step to evaluate this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA
Repeat testing of CD4-cell count and HIV viral load

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV drug resistance testing is indicated in patients with suspected virologic failure, but this patient has no evidence of failure; he had an undetectable viral load and normal CD4-cell count one month ago, indicating an adequate response to ART.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin antibody and total IgA is used to evaluate for celiac disease or gluten intolerance, which may be more common in patients with autoimmune thyroid disease. Although celiac disease can cause diarrhea and weight loss, it would not explain this patient’s other symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has classic signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis, including an elevated heart rate, palpitations, loose stools, anxiety, insomnia, weight loss, tremor, and mildly elevated aminotransferase levels. Thyroid function testing should be the next step in evaluation.

This patient’s thyrotoxicosis is likely due to Graves disease mediated by immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a condition that can occur after initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART) as patients rapidly regain immune function. IRIS often manifests early during immune reconstitution, but IRIS-associated Graves disease (which is rare) typically occurs later. One report cites a mean time of 20 months from ART initiation to Graves disease, while others cite ranges of up to 3 to 4 years. IRIS-associated Graves disease tends to occur in people who have significant immunocompromise initially and then experience a substantial rise in CD4-cell count after ART initiation (as in this case). Given that most patients do not have preexisting thyroid autoantibodies before initiating ART, IRIS-induced Graves disease is hypothesized to be mediated by de novo production of CD4+ T cells that target thyroid antigens rather than by exacerbation of preexisting subclinical disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step to address palpitations, tremor, anxiety, and weight loss in a patient whose HIV infection is well controlled on antiretroviral therapy and who has no obvious signs of current infection is to perform thyroid function testing to evaluate for thyrotoxicosis mediated by immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is useful to evaluate for cardiac dysfunction, which may predispose a patient to arrhythmia. HIV-associated dilated cardiomyopathy has been reported in the literature. However, this patient has no other signs of heart failure, and cardiac dysfunction would not explain his other symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

CD4-cell count and HIV viral load testing are used to determine response to ART. Repeat testing would be unlikely to yield a diagnosis in this patient, who has been symptomatic for at least 6 weeks, had a normal CD4-cell count and viral load one month ago, and has no current evidence of infection by history or physical examination.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman requests HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP). She has had reciprocal oral sex and receptive vaginal sex without condoms with two men in the past 6 months, most recently one month ago. Three months ago, she sought screening for sexually transmitted infections at an urgent care center, and a vaginal nucleic acid amplification test was positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae; she was treated with a single intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone. The urgent care clinician recommended that she use condoms consistently, but she has not been able to do so. She currently has no symptoms and has not had any fever, lymphadenopathy, sore throat, rash, or other symptoms within the past month.
Test results from today’s visit include a negative HIV antigen/antibody test, a negative treponemal antibody test, and negative nucleic acid amplification testing for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in the throat and vagina. The patient’s estimated creatinine clearance is 110 mL/min. Hepatitis B serologies are compatible with prior vaccination, and a hepatitis C antibody test is negative. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following next steps in management is best?

choices.text: Recommend that the patient use condoms for all sexual contacts; do not prescribe any medication now
Obtain an HIV-1 RNA assay, and if negative, prescribe tenofovir alafenamide-emtricitabine
Recommend that the patient stop having sex

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

For heterosexually active people (as in this case), guidelines recommend HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in three groups of individuals:

• Those who have sex with people with HIV (especially if the partner is not virologically suppressed on antiretroviral therapy)
• Those diagnosed with gonorrhea or syphilis within the past 6 months
• Those who do not consistently use condoms during sex

Three medications are approved for PrEP in the United States: oral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine (TDF-FTC), oral tenofovir alafenamide-emtricitabine (TAF-FTC), and long-acting injectable cabotegravir. Of note, TAF-FTC is not recommended or approved for people whose HIV risk stems from receptive vaginal sex because this medication has not been studied in this population.

Patients who are eligible for PrEP should undergo a baseline evaluation that includes:

• Screening for symptoms of acute HIV in the past 4 weeks and a combined HIV antigen/antibody assay, to exclude preexisting HIV infection
• Estimation of serum creatinine clearance for oral PrEP (should be ≥60 mL/min for TDF-FTC and ≥30 mL/min for TAF-FTC)
• Testing for hepatitis B (for oral PrEP) and hepatitis C
• Screening for gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis
• Assessment for pregnancy in those who could become pregnant

Once PrEP is initiated, patients should undergo periodic testing for HIV (with antigen/antibody and HIV-1 RNA assays), for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and for pregnancy. Oral PrEP also requires periodic monitoring of serum creatinine levels.

Key learning point: HIV preexposure prophylaxis should be offered to any sexually active person at increased risk for HIV — or to anyone who asks for it, even if they do not report behaviors that put them at risk for acquiring HIV.

B) INCORRECT:

Consistent condom use significantly reduces the risk of acquiring STIs, including HIV, but many people do not use condoms in all sexual encounters. This patient has not been able to use condoms consistently, so other HIV prevention strategies, such as PrEP, are warranted.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a negative HIV antigen/antibody test, no recent antiretroviral exposure, and no recent symptoms of acute HIV infection, obtaining an HIV-1 RNA assay is unnecessary before prescribing PrEP and could introduce delays in the initiation of PrEP. TAF-FTC is not recommended or approved for people whose HIV risk stems from receptive vaginal sex because this medication has not been studied in this population.

D) INCORRECT:

TAF-FTC-bictegravir is a treatment regimen for established HIV infection; it is not a recommended regimen for PrEP.

E) INCORRECT:

Although abstaining from sex would prevent sexual acquisition of HIV, it is not practical for many people and should not be the only strategy recommended for a person at high risk for HIV infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents for follow-up 4 months after starting injectable cabotegravir for HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP). He has reciprocal oral sex and insertive and receptive anal sex with men, often without use of condoms.
He has not experienced any adverse effects with PrEP and has received all of his injections on time. He has no symptoms today.
In addition to a combined HIV antigen/antibody assay and screening tests for other sexually transmitted infections, which one of the following tests is indicated for this patient today?

choices.text: Urinalysis and measurement of urine sediment
Measurement of aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal toxicity is rare in people taking PrEP but is more common with tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine (TDF-FTC) than with tenofovir alafenamide-emtricitabine (TAF-FTC). A urinalysis and urine sediment level would be reasonable to obtain if a patient had a significant decline in renal function while taking PrEP, but these tests are not recommended for routine monitoring, particularly with cabotegravir, which does not have major renal toxicities.

B) CORRECT:

People taking HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) require periodic laboratory monitoring for HIV acquisition. For patients taking cabotegravir, this testing should consist of both a combined HIV antigen/antibody assay and an HIV-1 RNA assay. The rationale for performing an HIV-1 RNA assay in addition to the antigen/antibody assay is that antiretroviral exposure, such as from ongoing PrEP, may delay antigen/antibody seroconversion.

People taking the other approved agents for PrEP, which are oral and based on tenofovir, should also be tested for HIV acquisition. For these agents, some guidelines recommend sending the combined HIV antigen/antibody assay alone, while others recommend also sending the HIV-1 RNA assay. In addition, patients on tenofovir-based PrEP should also have their serum creatinine levels measured regularly to estimate creatinine clearance. These measurements should be obtained at the first quarterly visit and then every 12 months in people <50 years of age with a baseline estimated creatinine clearance ≥90 mL/min and at least every 6 months otherwise.

Additional monitoring in people taking PrEP should include:

• Pregnancy testing in those who could become pregnant
• Screening for syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia depending on sexual history
• Ongoing assessment of adherence and HIV risk (and thus the need for continued PrEP)

Key learning point: Routine laboratory monitoring for people taking HIV preexposure prophylaxis with cabotegravir includes HIV antigen/antibody testing, HIV-1 RNA testing, and screening tests for other sexually transmitted infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine monitoring of blood counts or hepatic enzymes is not recommended during PrEP use.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine monitoring of blood counts or hepatic enzymes is not recommended during PrEP use.

E) INCORRECT:

Use of TDF-FTC for PrEP is associated with a small decline in bone mineral density, but the clinical significance of this decline is unclear, and bone changes are not seen with cabotegravir. Routine measurement of bone mineral density in people taking PrEP is not recommended.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with his wife for a routine visit. He was diagnosed with HIV-1 infection 5 years ago, started antiretroviral therapy at the time, and has adhered to the medication as prescribed. His HIV-1 RNA level has been consistently undetectable for the past 4.5 years, with testing performed every 6 months.
He is sexually active with his wife, and they would like to conceive a child. She has no other sex partners and does not inject drugs. Last month, she tested negative for HIV. The patient asks about the risk of transmitting HIV to her if they have condomless vaginal sex.
What is the best answer to this patient’s question?

choices.text: Condomless sex is not advisable, and the couple should pursue in vitro fertilization instead
The patient’s wife should take postexposure prophylaxis with dolutegravir and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine within 72 hours after condomless sex
The patient should wait until he has had an undetectable HIV viral load for 7 years before attempting conception through condomless sex
Provided that the patient’s HIV-1 RNA level remains undetectable, condomless sex is associated with effectively no risk of HIV transmission
The patient’s wife should begin preexposure prophylaxis with tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine before they engage in condomless sex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This couple does not need to avoid condomless sex or pursue in vitro fertilization for the sake of HIV prevention, nor is there any indication for the patient’s wife to take HIV postexposure prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

This couple does not need to avoid condomless sex or pursue in vitro fertilization for the sake of HIV prevention, nor is there any indication for the patient’s wife to take HIV postexposure prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

The shortest duration of virologic suppression required to eliminate transmission risk is unknown, but evidence suggests that sexual transmission does not occur once undetectable viral loads have been maintained for 6 months. Therefore, this patient does not need to wait 7 years before engaging in condomless sex.

D) CORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) that suppresses HIV RNA has been shown to effectively prevent sexual transmission of the virus, even if a condom is not used. This concept, known as “Undetectable equals Untransmittable” or “U = U”, was demonstrated in a large randomized controlled trial conducted among heterosexual couples and in observational studies conducted among both heterosexual couples and men who have sex with men. The use of ART as a prevention strategy has been endorsed by public health authorities around the world, including the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Key learning point: People with HIV who achieve undetectable HIV viral loads by taking antiretroviral therapy do not transmit HIV through sex, even if a condom is not used.

E) INCORRECT:

Because consistent virologic suppression effectively eliminates the risk of transmission, the use of HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in a scenario like this is deemed optional but not necessary and would simply add risk without any clear benefit. Guidelines from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services state that “the partner without HIV can choose to take PrEP even if the partner with HIV has achieved viral suppression,” but the benefits of this approach are not clear. If the patient’s viral load was not consistently suppressed or if the patient’s wife had other risk factors for HIV acquisition (e.g., condomless sex with other partners or injection-drug use), then PrEP would be more clearly beneficial.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old girl who was born via cesarean section at full term is brought into a clinic in the United States by her mother for a routine postnatal visit.
The mother is living with HIV and was recently diagnosed with hepatitis C virus infection. At the time of delivery, her HIV viral load was 1300 copies/mL, and her CD4 count was 830 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600). She is currently taking standard antiretroviral therapy with tenofovir-emtricitabine and ritonavir-boosted atazanavir. Combination antiretroviral therapy is initiated in the infant.
The mother asks about the appropriateness of breastfeeding.
What advice is most appropriate to give this child’s mother about breastfeeding?

choices.text: Encourage formula feeding to minimize the risk of HIV transmission
Encourage formula feeding to reduce the risk of neonatal toxicity that may be associated with the presence of antiretroviral drugs in the breast milk
Encourage breastfeeding for the first 4 months of the infant’s life
Encourage breastfeeding supplemented with some formula feeding
Encourage formula feeding to minimize the risk of hepatitis C virus transmission

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

All mothers with HIV should be counseled about the risks of HIV transmission through breast milk. In resource-rich areas, where formula is accessible, affordable, and safe, women with incompletely suppressed viral loads or low CD4-cell counts should be counseled to avoid breastfeeding in order to prevent postnatal transmission of HIV.

Clinicians should engage in evidence-based counseling to support shared decision-making about infant feeding. For women with virologic suppression during pregnancy and in the postpartum period, breastfeeding poses a low (<1%) risk of HIV transmission, but the risk is not zero. Women who want to eliminate this risk completely should be counseled to feed their infant with formula or with donor milk from a milk bank.

In low-resource areas where there are fewer safe alternatives to breastfeeding, it is recommended that breastfeeding mothers receive combination antiretroviral therapy and that their infants also receive a 6-week course of nevirapine. The benefits of breast milk in the absence of a safe water supply outweigh the potential adverse effects of antiretroviral medications in breast milk and the risk of HIV acquisition.

This infant should be considered at high risk for perinatal HIV transmission, given the incompletely suppressed maternal viral load (>1000 copies); thus, in addition to counseling against breastfeeding, combination antiretroviral therapy should be initiated in the infant.

Other infectious contraindications to breastfeeding include infection with maternal human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 or 2; untreated brucellosis; active, untreated tuberculosis; and the presence of any infected lesions on the breast, such as boils, impetigo, or lesions caused by herpes simplex virus. Women with active tuberculosis can resume breastfeeding after they have been treated for at least 2 weeks and are no longer infectious.

Key learning point: In areas where infant formula is accessible, affordable, and free, women with HIV should be counseled to avoid breastfeeding if their CD4-cell count is low, their viral load is not suppressed, or they want to completely eliminate the risk of transmitting HIV to their infant.

B) INCORRECT:

While some antiretroviral drugs do pass into breast milk, the concentrations are usually low and are unlikely to cause significant harm to the infant.

C) INCORRECT:

In resource-rich areas, where formula is accessible, affordable, and safe, women with incompletely suppressed viral loads should be counseled to avoid breastfeeding in order to prevent postnatal transmission of HIV.

D) INCORRECT:

In resource-rich areas, where formula is accessible, affordable, and safe, women with incompletely suppressed viral loads should be counseled to avoid breastfeeding in order to prevent postnatal transmission of HIV.

E) INCORRECT:

There are currently no data to suggest that hepatitis C virus (HCV) is transmitted by human breast milk, and HCV infection, even with detectable viral load, is not a contraindication to breastfeeding in the absence of HIV.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician for routine screening for sexually transmitted diseases. He reports having had unprotected sexual intercourse 4 months ago while on vacation in Greece. He recalls experiencing fever and body aches a few weeks later but is currently asymptomatic. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



HIV enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay
positive


Anti-HIV-1 antibodies
positive


Anti-gp120 antibodies
positive


Rapid plasma reagin
negative


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


HIV viral load
1980 copies/mL


Blood



CD4+ T-lymphocyte count
640 mm3


CD8+ T-lymphocyte count
1050 mm3 (150–1000/mm3)


Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-gp120 antibodies typically develop during the early stages of untreated HIV infection and can increase over time as the immune system responds to the virus. These antibodies are part of the broader humoral response to HIV. Anti-gp120 antibody titers are typically high in the initial phase of infection and do not have prognostic significance.
Image Description:

Graph showing typical cell counts, antibody levels, and viral loads during different stages of untreated HIV infection/AIDS

The dashed line at the level of 500 cells/mm3 represents a state of moderate immunocompromise.

CD4+ or CD8+ thresholds at which select common opportunistic infections most frequently occur:
I (< 200 cells/mm3): pneumocystis pneumonia, histoplasma capsulatum
II (< 100 cells/mm3): cryptococcal meningitis, candida esophagitis, cerebral toxoplasmosis
III (< 50 cells/mm3): CMV infection, atypical mycobacterial infections

B) INCORRECT:

CD4 count correlates with overall immunity and is an important prognostic factor throughout HIV infection. However, CD4 count is often normal (> 500 cells/mm3) in the initial stages and is therefore not the most important prognostic factor in this patient. In the advanced stages of untreated HIV infection, CD4 count often falls < 200 cells/mm3. CD4 count typically rises with effective antiretroviral therapy and helps determine the optimal timing to initiate prophylaxis against opportunistic infections.

C) INCORRECT:

HIV-1 is associated with a slightly higher risk of transmission and faster disease progression than HIV-2. A different factor has better prognostic value in the early stages of HIV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

CD8+ T-lymphocytes are important for the initial control of HIV infection as they suppress viral replication through cytotoxic mechanisms. CD8 count is typically elevated in the initial phase of infection because of immune activation and proliferation in response to the virus. However, a high CD8 count and decreased CD4+/CD8+ ratio do not necessarily reflect the overall health of the immune system or effective control of the virus; therefore, they do not have prognostic significance and are not used to guide treatment.

E) CORRECT:

The viral load at the beginning of the clinical latency stage (i.e., the viral set point) is a key factor in the prognosis and management of HIV infection. A low viral load, as observed in this patient, suggests a potentially slower progression to AIDS. By contrast, a high viral load (e.g., > 100,000 copies/mL) is associated with increased viral replication and destruction of CD4+ T-lymphocytes, resulting in more severe immunodeficiency and a poorer prognosis.

Although a high CD4 count is also a positive prognostic indicator, its relevance in the early stages of HIV infection is limited because CD4 typically declines significantly years after initial infection. Consequently, viral load is a more immediate and reliable marker of disease activity and progression in the early stages of infection.
Image Description:

Graph showing typical cell counts, antibody levels, and viral loads during different stages of untreated HIV infection/AIDS

The dashed line at the level of 500 cells/mm3 represents a state of moderate immunocompromise.

CD4+ or CD8+ thresholds at which select common opportunistic infections most frequently occur:
I (< 200 cells/mm3): pneumocystis pneumonia, histoplasma capsulatum
II (< 100 cells/mm3): cryptococcal meningitis, candida esophagitis, cerebral toxoplasmosis
III (< 50 cells/mm3): CMV infection, atypical mycobacterial infections
questions.hint: This patient is in the clinical latency stage of HIV infection (asymptomatic chronic infection), which can last for more than 10 years.

questions.text: A 2300-g (5-lb 1-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 45 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV RNA testing is indicated 14-21 days, 1-2 months, and 4-6 months after birth in infants exposed to HIV.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV antibody testing is not advised for children < 18 months of age, as maternal antibodies still present in the infant's bloodstream can act as confounding factors and invalidate the test.

C) INCORRECT:

Zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine are recommended for HIV PEP in infants born to HIV-positive mothers with HIV and a viral load of ≥ 50 copies/mL. However, a three-drug regimen is not recommended for a mother with a viral load < 50 copies/mL because of the greater risk of adverse effects, such as neutropenia and anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Because HIV transmission will have severe consequences for the neonate, minimization of transmission risk is of paramount importance. Simple reassurance is inappropriate, as other options can help reduce the rate of transmission.

E) CORRECT:

For infants born to mothers with HIV and a viral load < 50 copies/mL, PEP with zidovudine for 4 weeks is recommended to prevent neonatal transmission of HIV. If the mother's viral load is ≥ 50 copies/mL, a two-drug regimen (zidovudine and nevirapine) or a three-drug regimen (zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine or raltegravir) is recommended.

See "Intrapartum management of HIV" table.
questions.hint: Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for infants born to mothers with HIV infection to decrease the risk of transmission.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to employee health services 30 minutes after a work-related incident. She works as a phlebotomist and reports that blood splashed into her right eye when she was drawing blood from a 30-year-old male patient. Immediately following the incident, she flushed her eye with water for several minutes. The patient from whom she drew blood was admitted for hemoptysis, weight loss, and night sweats. He is an intravenous drug user and is sexually active with several male and female partners. The phlebotomist has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to drawing her blood for viral serologies, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of raltegravir (or dolutegravir), tenofovir, and emtricitabine is the preferred three-drug regimen for HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) following high-risk occupational exposure. The overall risk of transmission is very low but depends on multiple factors, including the type of exposure, the viral load of the source patient, and, in the case of a needle-stick injury, the type of needle involved. While the HIV status of the source patient is unknown, he has multiple risk factors for HIV infection (IV drug user, sexually active), and PEP should be offered as soon as possible, ideally within a few hours but at least within 72 hours.

Other steps that should be taken immediately after occupational exposure include testing the source person for HCV (HCV Ab or HCV RNA), HBV (HBV surface Ag), and HIV (HIV Ag/Ab or HIV Ab, rapid test preferred). Nucleic acid amplification testing (e.g., viral load testing) should not be performed as an initial screening test for HIV because it has a higher rate of false positives than antibody-based tests, and, furthermore, an undetectable HIV viral load in the source patient or the exposed patient does not rule out HIV transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of tenofovir and emtricitabine is recommended for HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV transmission in patients who are HIV-negative but are at risk of HIV infection (e.g., individuals with a serodiscordant sexual partner or those engaging in high-risk sexual activity). This patient has had a recent occupational exposure, however, meaning a different step is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance would be indicated if there were no true exposure identified, e.g., if the source patient's blood came into contact with skin that was intact or the exposure involved a noninfectious bodily fluid (e.g., feces, saliva, vomit). However, blood coming into contact with the eye is considered a high-risk exposure and this patient is at risk of contracting a bloodborne pathogen; reassurance would be insufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

Sofosbuvir and velpatasvir are used for the treatment of hepatitis C (HCV) infection. Currently, there is no postexposure prophylaxis regimen available for patients at risk of HCV transmission. Recommendations for postexposure HCV testing differ, but treatment is only recommended for documented infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine should be administered in cases of occupational exposure when the HBV vaccination status of the health care worker is incomplete or unknown. This woman's vaccinations are up-to-date and, as a healthcare worker, this would include complete HBV vaccination. No further action is required to prevent hepatitis B infection.
questions.hint: This phlebotomist's mucous membranes were contaminated by blood from a source patient with risk factors for a bloodborne disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and fatigue. He also has nonbloody diarrhea with up to 4 bowel movements per day that began about 2 weeks ago. This morning, he could not go to work because of chills and generalized muscle aches. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender preauricular, cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are two tender, shallow, sharply demarcated ulcers with white bases and surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa. The left tonsil is enlarged with no exudate. Several muscles on his arms and legs are tender to palpation with no weakness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results from a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of nonspecific symptoms such as fever, fatigue, diarrhea, and myalgias, along with findings of generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, nonexudative tonsillitis, and oral mucosal ulcers in a patient with multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use suggests acute retroviral syndrome. The best initial test to diagnose HIV infection is an antigen/antibody combination test (screening test), which detects both HIV antigen (p24) and anti-HIV antibodies as early as 14 days after transmission. If the combination test is negative and acute HIV infection is strongly suspected, an HIV RNA test (viral load test) may be performed because this test can detect an infection before seroconversion (5–10 days after transmission). In patients with a positive screening test, an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay is used to confirm the diagnosis. If the patient has a positive screening test but the confirmatory test is negative, an HIV RNA test must be performed. Because patients with acute HIV infection have an elevated viral load, the probability of HIV transmission is increased. Patients should start antiretroviral therapy as soon as possible and be counseled on reducing the risk of HIV transmission.

Key learning point: Acute retroviral syndrome presents with nonspecific symptoms and generalized lymphadenopathy; diagnosis is confirmed with serum HIV antigen/antibody testing, followed by HIV RNA testing if suspicion remains despite a negative initial screen.

B) INCORRECT:

A colonoscopy with intestinal biopsies is used to confirm the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which can manifest with fever, fatigue, and nonbloody diarrhea. Moreover, IBD can be associated with aphthous stomatitis manifesting with oral mucosal ulcers. However, patients with IBD typically present with chronic abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea, which are not seen here. Additionally, IBD is not commonly associated with generalized lymphadenopathy and myalgias.

C) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture is used to diagnose acute bacterial tonsillitis (most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes). This condition manifests with sudden onset of fever, tonsillitis, and lymphadenopathy. However, patients with acute bacterial tonsillitis typically present with exudative tonsillitis and tender lymphadenopathy restricted to cervical lymph nodes whereas this patient's oral findings are nonexudative and his lymphadenopathy is generalized. Moreover, bacterial tonsillitis usually does not cause myalgia, diarrhea, or oral ulcerations.

D) INCORRECT:

Heterophile agglutination test is used for patients with suspected infectious mononucleosis. This condition causes fever, fatigue, myalgias, tonsillitis, and generalized lymphadenopathy. However, tonsillitis in patients with mononucleosis is exudative and lymphadenopathy is usually tender. Additionally, diarrhea and oral ulcerations are not common. Finally, this patient is 35 years of age whereas patients with mononucleosis are usually younger (peak incidence: 15–24 years of age).

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional lymph node biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis of lymphoma, which can manifest with fever, fatigue, and nontender lymphadenopathy. While lymphadenopathy in Hodgkin lymphoma is usually localized, non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) can cause generalized lymphadenopathy, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, aggressive forms of NHL can have a very acute onset. However, diarrhea, oral mucosal ulcers, and myalgia are not common in patients with lymphoma. Night sweats and weight loss are constitutional symptoms expected in patients with lymphoma.
questions.hint: Early detection of this patient's condition can prevent long-term complications such as lymphoma, candidiasis, and disseminated mycobacterial infection.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with HIV infection seeks advice about HIV treatment and initiation of antiretroviral therapy. He feels well, has never taken antiretrovirals, and has a CD4 count of 450 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600) and an HIV viral load of 10,000 copies/mL. An HIV genotype shows no resistance mutations. Baseline laboratory results are normal. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate antiretroviral therapy if the CD4 count drops below 350 cells per mm3
Initiate antiretroviral therapy when the HIV viral load is >100,000 copies/mL
Initiate antiretroviral therapy if toxoplasmosis develops

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Both the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and the International AIDS Society-USA recommend antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all patients with HIV, regardless of CD4-cell count. In a randomized controlled trial conducted in Haiti, patients who initiated ART with CD4 counts of 200 to 350 cell per mm3 had a lower mortality rate than those who deferred treatment until they developed a CD4 count below 200 cells per mm3 or an AIDS-defining complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is unwarranted unless a patient’s CD4 count is less than 200 cells per mm3.

C) INCORRECT:

Waiting until the HIV viral load is >100,000 copies/mL is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

It is not appropriate to wait to start ART until a patient develops an AIDS-related complication, such as cerebral toxoplasmosis, which generally occurs when the CD4 count is below 200 cells per mm3.

E) CORRECT:

Both the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and the International AIDS Society-USA recommend antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all patients with HIV, regardless of CD4-cell count. This strategy is supported by evidence from large observational studies as well as randomized controlled trials. Moreover, data from the international HPTN 052 trial showed that in HIV-serodiscordant couples, ART initiation in people with HIV and CD4 counts between 350 and 550 cells per mm3 reduced sexual transmission of the virus to their uninfected partners and also reduced the frequency of HIV-related clinical events, such as extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

Key learning point: Antiretroviral therapy is recommended for all with HIV infection regardless of CD4-cell count.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports one week of severe throat pain and difficulty swallowing. She states that she has not experienced fever, rhinorrhea, or cough and has had no recent sick contacts. She notes a gradual 11-kg weight loss during the past 6 months. She reports no use of alcohol or illicit drugs. On physical examination, she is noticeably thin and does not appear acutely ill. Her vital signs are normal. She does not have orthostatic hypotension. Her buccal mucosa and soft palate exhibit white plaques on an erythematous base, which scrape off with a tongue blade. She also has shotty bilateral cervical adenopathy. Which one of the following tests should be done promptly in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is not necessary in this patient at this time. Endoscopy should be performed if the symptoms do not readily respond to antifungal treatment. Early endoscopy would also be appropriate when a cause for dysphagia is not readily apparent.

B) INCORRECT:

White oral plaques on an erythematous base on the buccal mucosa are not suggestive of infectious mononucleosis, streptococcal pharyngitis, or gonococcal pharyngitis; testing for these conditions is therefore not warranted.

Patients with gonococcal pharyngitis may develop fever, severe sore throat, dysuria, and a characteristic greenish exudate.

C) INCORRECT:

White oral plaques on an erythematous base on the buccal mucosa are not suggestive of infectious mononucleosis, streptococcal pharyngitis, or gonococcal pharyngitis; testing for these conditions is therefore not warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

White oral plaques on an erythematous base on the buccal mucosa are not suggestive of infectious mononucleosis, streptococcal pharyngitis, or gonococcal pharyngitis; testing for these conditions is therefore not warranted. Patients with infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, may develop a severe pharyngitis and enlarged tonsils with a pustular exudate similar to that seen in strep throat; half of patients may also have petechiae on the roof of the mouth and prominent swollen lymph nodes.

E) CORRECT:

Oral candidiasis classically manifests with white oral plaques on an erythematous base that scrape off with a tongue blade. Most cases are caused by the yeast Candida albicans. The diagnosis is most often made clinically during a physical examination; however, potassium hydroxide staining and culture of oral scrapings can confirm the diagnosis. If oropharyngeal candidiasis is associated with odynophagia or dysphagia, then esophageal candidiasis should be suspected.

Esophageal candidiasis is an AIDS-defining illness. Thus, patients with this condition should undergo HIV antibody testing. Patients with esophageal candidiasis can be treated with a trial of fluconazole.

Key learning point: Patients with esophageal candidiasis should routinely be tested for infection with HIV.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is hospitalized for fever, headache, rash, and vomiting. He was well until 8 days ago, when he developed fever, chills, diaphoresis, a throbbing frontal headache, sore throat, diffuse myalgias and arthralgias, and a maculopapular rash on his torso, arms, and legs. He has not traveled recently. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F). He has bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy; the oropharynx is erythematous, without exudate or tonsillar enlargement. Neck flexion causes discomfort. An erythematous, blanching rash covers his chest and upper back. Laboratory studies show normal findings for complete blood count, serum electrolytes, total protein, and liver and kidney function tests. Blood cultures show no growth. A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows clear cerebrospinal fluid with a normal glucose level, a protein level of 132 mg/dL, and a leukocyte count of 23/mm3 (72% lymphocytes). Which of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ehrlichiosis manifests with fever and headache; a maculopapular rash develops in some patients. Leukopenia, lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum liver aminotransferase levels are often noted in patients with ehrlichiosis but were not present in this case; cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis is rare.

B) CORRECT:

Acute-onset fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, rash, and aseptic meningitis represent a constellation of symptoms and signs that characterize acute HIV infection.

Key learning point: Acute HIV infection manifests with acute onset of fever, rash, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, myalgias, and aseptic meningitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Typhoid fever manifests with fever and gastrointestinal symptoms in a patient with a recent history of travel. A few rose spots may be evident, but diffuse maculopapular rash and aseptic meningitis are rare, and blood cultures are typically positive for Salmonella typhi.

D) INCORRECT:

Fever, night sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss are characteristic features of disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection; a mononucleosis-like syndrome and aseptic meningitis is not suggestive of this infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis can cause posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, pharyngitis, and a maculopapular rash, but Epstein-Barr virus infection rarely develops in middle age and is not commonly associated with aseptic meningitis.
questions.hint: Fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness in conjunction with CSF analysis (i.e., nonpurulent appearance with elevated lymphocytes) are consistent with aseptic meningitis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with HIV comes to the office for a routine follow-up examination. He has been nonadherent with his antiretroviral medication regimen for several years. He appears chronically ill and fatigued. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 405/mm3. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Encapsulated yeast on India ink staining of blood

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Violaceous skin lesions in a patient with HIV describe Kaposi sarcoma. HIV patients are at a higher risk of Kaposi sarcoma at variable CD4 counts, even above 400/mm3.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary cavitations in a patient with HIV may be caused by pulmonary aspergillosis, pneumocystis pneumonia, or tuberculosis. HIV patients have an increased risk of pulmonary aspergillosis primarily at CD4 counts below 100/mm3, pneumocystis pneumonia primarily at CD4 below 200/mm3, and tuberculosis primarily at CD4 below 400/mm3.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal mucosa with white plaques in a patient with HIV describes Candida esophagitis. Risk of this infection increases primarily among patients with CD4 counts below 100/mm3.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotton-wool spots on the fundus in a patient with HIV is a classic description of CMV retinitis. HIV patients with CD4 counts below 50/mm3 are at higher risk of CMV infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Encapsulated yeast on India ink staining of blood or cerebrospinal fluid in a patient with HIV describes systemic infection with Cryptococcus neoformans. The risk of cryptococcal meningitis increases especially among patients with CD4 counts below 100/mm3.
questions.hint: This patient has a CD4 T-cell count below 500/mm3, but greater than 200/mm3, putting him at risk for several opportunistic infections, including oral hairy leukoplakia, oral thrush, HHV-8 infection, and squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman requests HIV preexposure prophylaxis. She has had reciprocal oral sex and receptive vaginal sex without condoms with two men in the past 6 months, most recently one month ago. She currently has no symptoms and has not had any fever, lymphadenopathy, sore throat, rash, or other symptoms within the past month. Test results from today’s visit include a negative HIV antigen/antibody test, a negative treponemal antibody test, and negative nucleic acid amplification testing for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in the throat and vagina. The patient’s estimated creatinine clearance is 110 mL/min. Hepatitis B serologies are compatible with prior vaccination, and a hepatitis C antibody test is negative. A pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following next steps in management is best?

choices.text: Recommend that the patient use condoms for all sexual contacts; do not prescribe any medication now
Obtain an HIV-1 RNA assay, and if negative, prescribe tenofovir alafenamide-emtricitabine
Recommend that the patient stop having sex

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Three medications are approved for PrEP in the United States: oral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine (TDF-FTC), oral tenofovir alafenamide-emtricitabine (TAF-FTC), and long-acting injectable cabotegravir. Of note, TAF-FTC is not recommended or approved for people whose HIV risk stems from receptive vaginal sex because this medication has not been studied in this population.

Patients who are eligible for PrEP should undergo a baseline evaluation that includes: (1) screening for symptoms of acute HIV in the past 4 weeks and a combined HIV antigen/antibody assay, to exclude preexisting HIV infection, (2) estimation of serum creatinine clearance for oral PrEP (should be ≥60 mL/min for TDF-FTC and ≥30 mL/min for TAF-FTC), (3) testing for hepatitis B (for oral PrEP) and hepatitis C, (4)screening for gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis, and (5) assessment for pregnancy in those who could become pregnant.

Once PrEP is initiated, patients should undergo periodic testing for HIV (with antigen/antibody and HIV-1 RNA assays), for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and for pregnancy. Oral PrEP also requires periodic monitoring of serum creatinine levels.

Key learning point: HIV preexposure prophylaxis should be offered to any sexually active person at increased risk for HIV — or to anyone who asks for it, even if they do not report behaviors that put them at risk for acquiring HIV.

B) INCORRECT:

Consistent condom use significantly reduces the risk of acquiring STIs, including HIV, but many people do not use condoms in all sexual encounters. This patient has not been able to use condoms consistently, so other HIV prevention strategies, such as PrEP, are warranted.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a negative HIV antigen/antibody test, no recent antiretroviral exposure, and no recent symptoms of acute HIV infection, obtaining an HIV-1 RNA assay is unnecessary before prescribing PrEP and could introduce delays in the initiation of PrEP. TAF-FTC is not recommended or approved for people whose HIV risk stems from receptive vaginal sex because this medication has not been studied in this population.

D) INCORRECT:

TAF-FTC-bictegravir is a treatment regimen for established HIV infection; it is not a recommended regimen for PrEP.

E) INCORRECT:

Although abstaining from sex would prevent sexual acquisition of HIV, it is not practical for many people and should not be the only strategy recommended for a person at high risk for HIV infection.
questions.hint: For heterosexually active people, guidelines recommend HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in three groups of individuals: those who have sex with people with HIV (especially if the partner is not virologically suppressed on antiretroviral therapy), those diagnosed with gonorrhea or syphilis within the past 6 months, and those who do not consistently use condoms during sex.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man, newly diagnosed with HIV, seeks guidance before engaging in sexual activities. What is the best recommendation?

choices.text: Inform his partner about his HIV before sexual contact
Wait for suppression before discussing his diagnosis with his partner
Request the public health department to inform his partner anonymously
Use barrier methods solely without mentioning his HIV diagnosis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Disclosing HIV status to a sexual partner before engaging in sexual activities is crucial for ethical and legal reasons. It allows the partner to make informed decisions and consider preventive measures like pre-exposure prophylaxis. This practice aligns with public health goals to reduce HIV transmission through open communication and informed consent, fostering trust and mutual understanding in relationships.

Key learning point: Individuals diagnosed with HIV should disclose their status to sexual partners to prevent transmission and ensure appropriate health measures are taken.

B) INCORRECT:

Waiting for viral suppression before disclosing HIV status increases transmission risk, as suppression can take weeks to months. Ethical guidelines advocate for early disclosure to allow partners to make informed health decisions and consider preventive measures.

C) INCORRECT:

Public health departments can notify partners anonymously, but this is typically for patients unwilling or unable to disclose their status. The patient is seeking guidance, indicating openness to direct disclosure and education on safe practices, making self-disclosure more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

While barrier methods like condoms reduce HIV transmission risk, relying solely on them without disclosing HIV status neglects the ethical and legal responsibility to inform partners. Disclosure is essential for comprehensive risk reduction and allows partners to make informed health decisions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is newly diagnosed with HIV after recent unprotected intercourse and shared needle use. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Offer testing to all potentially exposed contacts
Delay evaluation until new symptoms appear
Obtain genotype screening from each contact
Initiate prophylactic therapy for all sexual partners

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Upon diagnosing a patient with HIV, it is crucial to identify and test all potentially exposed contacts, including sexual partners and needle-sharing individuals. This strategy facilitates early detection and treatment of new cases, reducing further transmission. It also allows for timely initiation of antiretroviral therapy and preventive measures, such as pre-exposure prophylaxis for uninfected individuals. Partner notification and counseling are integral to public health efforts in controlling HIV spread.

Key learning point: In the context of a newly diagnosed HIV patient, sexual partners or individuals with potential blood exposure should be offered HIV testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Delaying evaluation until symptoms appear overlooks the latent phase of HIV, during which significant immunologic damage can occur. Early evaluation with laboratory assessments is essential to gauge disease progression, plan management, and screen for coinfections. Clinical guidelines recommend immediate evaluation upon diagnosis to reduce long-term morbidity.

C) INCORRECT:

Genotype resistance testing is used to guide antiretroviral therapy in confirmed HIV-positive patients, not as a screening tool for contacts. Contacts should receive counseling and diagnostic testing for HIV. Genotypic analysis is performed on viral material from confirmed infections, not on potentially uninfected individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Initiating prophylactic therapy for all sexual partners without assessing each partner's exposure details and HIV status is not recommended. Partners should first receive counseling and HIV testing. Post-exposure prophylaxis or pre-exposure prophylaxis is considered individually, based on exposure timing and HIV status. Immediate management focuses on evaluating the patient and providing targeted partner services.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with HIV infection comes to your clinic to discuss HIV treatment and starting antiretroviral therapy. He feels well and has never taken antiretroviral medications. His CD4 count is 450 cells/μL (500–2000), and his HIV viral load is 10,000 copies/mL. HIV genotyping shows no resistance mutations. Baseline laboratory results are normal. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate antiretroviral therapy when the HIV viral load is >100,000 copies/mL.
Initiate antiretroviral therapy if toxoplasmosis develops.
Initiate antiretroviral therapy if the CD4 count drops below 350 cells per mm3.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Waiting until the HIV viral load is > 100,000 copies/mL is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

It is not appropriate to wait to start ART until a patient develops an AIDS-related complication, such as cerebral toxoplasmosis, which generally occurs when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/μL.

C) CORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy is recommended for all patients with HIV, regardless of CD4-cell count. This strategy is supported by evidence from large observational studies as well as randomized controlled trials. Moreover, data from the international HPTN 052 trial showed that in HIV-serodiscordant couples, ART initiation in people with HIV and CD4 counts between 350 and 550 cells/μL reduced sexual transmission of the virus to their uninfected partners and also reduced the frequency of HIV-related clinical events, such as extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

Key learning point: Antiretroviral therapy is recommended for all with HIV infection regardless of CD4-cell count.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy is recommended for all patients with HIV, regardless of CD4-cell count. In a randomized controlled trial conducted in Haiti, patients who initiated ART with CD4 counts of 200 to 350 cells/μL had a lower mortality rate than those who deferred treatment until they developed a CD4 count below 200 cells/μL or an AIDS-defining complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is unwarranted unless a patient’s CD4 count is less than 200 cells/μL.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with HIV comes to your clinic for routine follow-up. He has not been adherent to his antiretroviral medication regimen for several years. He reports chronic fatigue. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 405 cells/μL (500–2000). At this CD4 count, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The risk of candidal esophagitis increases primarily among patients with CD4 counts below 100/μL.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (especially cryptococcal meningitis) increases among patients with CD4 counts below 100/μL.

C) CORRECT:

As the CD4 count declines, the immune system is weakened, and many pathological processes may occur. AIDS (also known as advanced HIV) is defined as the development of an AIDS-defining condition or a CD4 count of < 200 cells/μL in HIV-infected patients. Most AIDS‑defining conditions occur only after the CD4 count falls below a specific threshold. However, some AIDS-defining conditions may occur at any CD4 count (but are more common when the CD4 count is < 500 cells/μL). Examples include invasive cervical cancer, Kaposi sarcoma, tuberculosis, HIV wasting syndrome, and HIV-associated dementia.

Key learning point: Some AIDS-defining conditions can occur even at relatively high CD4 counts.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

D) INCORRECT:

HIV patients with CD4 counts below 50/μL are at higher risk of CMV retinitis and CMV colitis.

E) INCORRECT:

HIV patients have an increased risk of pneumocystis pneumonia primarily at CD4 counts below 200/μL.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with 3 weeks of fever, myalgia, and sore throat. He reports a generalized rash that started during the first week of his illness and disappeared after a few days. During the second week of his illness, he saw his primary care doctor and was treated empirically with azithromycin for 5 days with no change in his symptoms. Vital signs are BP, 128/76; P, 92; T, 38.4°C (101.2°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows pharyngeal edema and hyperemia and bilateral nontender cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 3,200/μL with 65% lymphocytes and a negative monospot test. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although infectious mononucleosis can present with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, this patient's presentation, including the early self-resolving maculopapular rash and negative monospot test, is more concerning for acute retroviral syndrome. In Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, rashes more commonly appear in response to antibiotic treatment rather than spontaneously. Additionally, monospot testing is unlikely to be false-negative after the first week of illness. EBV serology is reasonable when clinical suspicion for infectious mononucleosis remains high despite a negative monospot test. However, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) testing should be the priority in this patient because missing acute HIV infection has significant implications for transmission risk and delayed treatment initiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Rapid streptococcal antigen testing is unlikely to be helpful, as this patient has already received empirical antibiotic treatment with azithromycin without improvement. Furthermore, this patient’s clinical presentation with generalized lymphadenopathy and leukopenia is not consistent with bacterial pharyngitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Throat culture is unlikely to be useful at this point, as this patient has already received empirical antibiotic treatment for presumed bacterial pharyngitis without improvement. Furthermore, the systemic symptoms with lymphadenopathy and leukopenia suggest a viral syndrome rather than localized bacterial infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharge with supportive care alone is inappropriate without establishing a definitive diagnosis in a patient with a 3-week mononucleosis-like syndrome that has not responded to empirical antibiotic treatment, particularly given the concerning constellation of fever and generalized lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic features of acute retroviral syndrome, including prolonged fever, myalgia, sore throat, early maculopapular rash that resolved, and generalized lymphadenopathy. The negative monospot test and lack of response to antibiotic therapy further support this diagnosis. Fourth-generation human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) testing can detect both p24 antigen and antibodies, allowing identification of infection approximately 14 days after transmission, which is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment initiation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV infection presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of polyuria, polydipsia, and progressive weakness. He was diagnosed with HIV 4 years ago and started on HAART containing tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, emtricitabine, and dolutegravir. Recent CD4 count is 650 cells/mm3 and viral load is undetectable. He was also recently diagnosed with diabetes and started on metformin and dapagliflozin 6 months ago. Vital signs are BP, 107/72; P, 98; R, 22; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Venous blood gas shows pH 7.31, PCO2 33 mm Hg. Laboratory results show sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 2.8 mEq/L, chloride 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate 16 mEq/L, glucose 90 mg/dL, phosphate 2.1 mg/dL, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows glucosuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate causes nephrotoxicity that can lead to Fanconi syndrome, a generalized proximal tubular dysfunction. This patient presents with classic findings of Fanconi syndrome, including normoglycemic glucosuria, hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and polyuria. While glucosuria despite normal serum glucose can also be explained by dapagliflozin which causes reversible inhibition of SGLT-2 in the proximal tubule, the constellation of findings in this patient suggests a more generalized proximal tubular disorder beyond selective SGLT-2 inhibition. Tenofovir-related renal toxicity is more frequent with prolonged treatment and often improves after discontinuation.

B) INCORRECT:

Metformin can cause lactic acidosis in patients with renal impairment, but this typically manifests with elevated lactate levels and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient's normal anion gap acidosis, normoglycemic glucosuria, proteinuria, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia suggest proximal tubular dysfunction rather than metformin toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Dapagliflozin causes reversible inhibition of SGLT-2 in the proximal tubule, leading to glucosuria as its intended mechanism of action. This patient's normal anion gap acidosis, proteinuria, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia suggest a more generalized proximal tubular disorder beyond selective SGLT-2 inhibition. Additionally, while SGLT-2 inhibitors can cause normoglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis, this would present with ketosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis rather than the hyperchloremic normal anion gap acidosis present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Emtricitabine is generally well-tolerated and does not cause significant nephrotoxicity or proximal tubular dysfunction. The adverse effects are typically limited to headache, nausea, and occasional skin hyperpigmentation, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's renal presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Dolutegravir can cause muscle inflammation and elevated creatinine kinase in rare cases, but it is not associated with proximal tubular dysfunction or Fanconi syndrome. The drug is generally well-tolerated from a renal standpoint and would not explain this patient's specific pattern of electrolyte and acid-base abnormalities.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and generalized lymphadenopathy. He reports unprotected sexual contact with a male partner 3 weeks ago. His fourth-generation HIV test result is positive, and confirmatory studies confirm HIV-1 infection. CD4 count is 450 cells/mm3 and viral load is 45,000 copies/mL. Blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain hepatitis B and C testing results before initiating HIV treatment
Prescribe emtricitabine PLUS tenofovir disoproxil fumarate PLUS dolutegravir for 28 days
Initiate antiretroviral therapy and provide counseling regarding the diagnosis and linkage to outpatient HIV care
Initiate trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prophylaxis for opportunistic infections

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiation of treatment should not be delayed for HIV resistance testing. Antiretroviral therapy should be started as soon as possible to prevent further disease progression.

B) INCORRECT:

While obtaining hepatitis B and C serology is an important part of the evaluation of newly diagnosed HIV, antiretroviral therapy and linkage to outpatient care are the immediate priorities. Initiation of treatment should not be delayed for hepatitis screening.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the postexposure prophylaxis regimen, which is indicated for individuals exposed to HIV within 72 hours of exposure, not for patients with confirmed HIV infection.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- All individuals with HIV infection, regardless of CD4 count, should begin antiretroviral therapy as soon as possible. Emergency department management includes counseling regarding the diagnosis and ensuring linkage to outpatient HIV care with multidisciplinary support, which is essential for patients with newly diagnosed HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Opportunistic infection prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is indicated for patients with CD4 counts < 200 cells/mm3. Prophylaxis is not indicated in this patient as his CD4 count is 450 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a 10-year history of well-controlled HIV presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of severe, constant epigastric pain radiating to his back. His antiretroviral regimen includes darunavir/cobicistat and tenofovir alafenamide/emtricitabine. He denies alcohol use. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and his abdomen is tender in the epigastrium. Laboratory studies show a lipase of 1250 U/L and a triglyceride level of 1600 mg/dL. His CD4 count is 650 cells/mm³, and his viral load is undetectable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) occurs when a patient with advanced immunosuppression starts antiretroviral therapy, leading to an exaggerated inflammatory response. This patient has a long-standing history of well-controlled HIV with a normal CD4 count, which is inconsistent with the typical timing and immunologic state required for IRIS to develop.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactic acidosis is a rare but serious side effect associated with older nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), such as didanosine and stavudine. This patient is on newer NRTIs (tenofovir alafenamide/emtricitabine), which have a much lower risk. Furthermore, lactic acidosis does not directly cause pancreatitis; rather, severe pancreatitis can lead to acidosis. This patient's clinical presentation is not suggestive of primary lactic acidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholelithiasis, or gallstones, is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the general population. Although gallstone pancreatitis cannot be definitively ruled out without imaging, this patient's severe hypertriglyceridemia makes a metabolic cause much more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Although HIV itself can be associated with pancreatitis, this typically occurs with advanced, uncontrolled disease or opportunistic infections. This patient has well-controlled HIV, with a high CD4 count and an undetectable viral load, making a direct viral effect highly unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Protease inhibitors, such as darunavir, are a well-known class of antiretroviral drugs that cause metabolic complications, including dyslipidemia (specifically hypertriglyceridemia and hypercholesterolemia) and insulin resistance. The mechanism involves interference with lipid-regulating proteins. Triglyceride levels exceeding 1000 mg/dL significantly increase the risk of pancreatitis. This patient's medication regimen, profound hypertriglyceridemia, and absence of other common causes, such as alcohol use, make the protease inhibitor the most likely cause.
questions.hint: This patient's pancreatitis is caused by severe hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman who is 38 weeks pregnant presents for evaluation. She has HIV infection and is receiving antiretroviral therapy irregularly. Her latest lab results show a viral load of 2,200 copies/mL. She has no other medical or obstetric complications. Physical examination is normal. She is concerned about measures to reduce the risk of transmitting HIV to her baby and asks about her delivery plan.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management option at this time?

choices.text: Planned vaginal delivery and intravenous zidovudine
Elective cesarean delivery before labor onset
Intrapartum nevirapine alone and allow vaginal delivery
Continue current antiretroviral therapy and await spontaneous labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous zidovudine reduces peripartum HIV transmission but is insufficient alone when maternal viral load is high. A viral load of 2,200 copies/mL increases transmission risk during vaginal delivery due to exposure to maternal blood and secretions. In such cases, cesarean delivery is preferred to minimize neonatal exposure.

B) CORRECT:

In pregnant women with HIV, the risk of vertical transmission correlates with maternal viral load. A viral load exceeding 1,000 copies/mL, as in this patient, indicates insufficient viral suppression. Elective cesarean delivery before labor onset reduces the infant's exposure to maternal blood and secretions, thereby minimizing transmission risk. This approach is particularly crucial when antiretroviral therapy adherence is inconsistent, leading to suboptimal viral control. Elective cesarean delivery is a key intervention to lower mother-to-child transmission risk in such clinical scenarios.

Key learning point: For HIV-positive pregnant women with a detectable viral load, a cesarean section is recommended to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum nevirapine alone is inadequate for preventing vertical transmission in patients with high viral loads. This patient’s viral load of 2,200 copies/mL and irregular antiretroviral therapy indicate suboptimal suppression. Cesarean delivery is recommended to reduce exposure to maternal blood and secretions during delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

Continuing antiretroviral therapy is crucial, but with a viral load of 2,200 copies/mL, additional measures are needed to reduce transmission risk. Awaiting spontaneous labor without modifying the delivery plan does not address the increased risk associated with higher viral loads.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fatigue, cough, and worsening shortness of breath for 2 weeks. He is currently experiencing homelessness. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 25 years ago but has never had any symptoms. He has always refused to take antiretroviral medication. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles over bilateral lower lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse, symmetrical interstitial infiltrates. His serum level of beta-d-glucan is elevated. Further testing shows a heterozygous mutation that prevents entry of HIV into macrophages. Which of the following proteins is most likely affected by the mutation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ICAM-1 are integrin receptors expressed on endothelial cells allowing attachment of other cells, including leukocytes. Rhinovirus binds to these receptors, initiating endocytosis of the virus particles into the cell. However, this receptor does not bind HIV and would, therefore, not affect HIV entry into macrophages.

B) CORRECT:

Fusion of HIV with host cells requires presence of CD4 receptor and a chemokine coreceptor (CCR5 in macrophages, and CCR5 or CXCR4 in T cells). CCR5 is utilized by HIV as the main coreceptor early in the course of infection, while CXCR4 is used later. Homozygous mutations of the CCR5 receptor (CCR5Δ32 deletion) give individuals immunity against HIV infection, while heterozygous mutations slow the course of the disease, as seen in this patient, who has not developed symptoms of HIV infection for 25 years.

Beta-d-glucan is a component of fungal cell walls. The elevated serum level of beta-d-glucan in this patient is a nonspecific indicator of fungal infection, e.g., due to Pneumocystis jirovecii.

C) INCORRECT:

Gp120 is an HIV envelope protein that the virus requires for docking onto and entering cells. The glycoprotein requires to be bound to two cell surface proteins, a receptor, and a coreceptor, to trigger internalization into a cell. It is expressed by HIV itself and is therefore not directly affected by mutations in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

CD21 is part of the B cell coreceptor complex and a receptor for EBV binding and virus entry into the cell. This receptor does not bind HIV and would, therefore, not affect HIV entry into macrophages.

E) INCORRECT:

CD4 surface proteins allow binding of CD4+ T cells to the MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells. HIV gp120 proteins bind to CD4 receptors, which exposes the coreceptor binding site on gp120 that is required for full docking and entry into the cell. However, the coreceptor, and not the CD4 surface protein, is most likely affected in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

CXCR4 is a chemokine receptor broadly expressed on white blood cells, such as CD4+ T cells and progenitor cells in the bone marrow. CXCR4 acts as a coreceptor for HIV entry into cells, though typically later in the course of the infection. However, CXCR4 is not expressed on macrophages.

G) INCORRECT:

P antigens are blood-group antigens that are used as receptors by parvovirus B19 for entry into erythroid progenitor cells. However, this receptor does not bind HIV. Mutation would, therefore, not affect HIV entry into macrophages.
questions.hint: The protein in question is a coreceptor for HIV entry into cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department in active labor. She has not had regular prenatal care. She has a history of HIV infection but is not currently on antiretroviral therapy. Her previous viral load is unknown. Treatment with intravenous zidovudine is begun to reduce perinatal transmission of the virus. Which of the following processes is most likely affected by this drug?

choices.text: Fusion of virus with T cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir) interfere with the integration of viral genome into host DNA, which impairs viral replication. Zidovudine is not an integrase inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Sofosbuvir is a nucleoside polymerase inhibitor used as an antiviral drug for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C infection. It is not used to treat HIV infections. Zidovudine does not interfere with RNA polymerase activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir, ritonavir) prevent the cleavage of viral polypeptides, which results in the production of immature, noninfectious viruses. Zidovudine is not a protease inhibitor.

D) CORRECT:

Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that is structurally similar to thymidine. However, instead of a hydroxyl group at the 3' end, it has an azido group that prevents the formation of 3'→5' phosphodiester linkages needed for DNA replication. Thus, after incorporation into the viral genome as a thymidine analog, it prevents the elongation of viral DNA by HIV viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. Zidovudine is the drug of choice for HIV-positive women in labor; there is no evidence that it has a teratogenic effect in humans.

The newborn should receive postpartum antiretroviral therapy, which significantly reduces the risk of perinatal transmission of HIV.

E) INCORRECT:

Fusion inhibitors (e.g., enfuvirtide, maraviroc) competitively bind to viral proteins and prevent the fusion of the virus with T cells. Zidovudine is not a fusion inhibitor.
questions.hint: Zidovudine is a nucleoside analog that lacks a hydroxyl group at the 3' end.
